Political ideology also plays a significant role, with views on government efforts against terrorism becoming more negative across the political spectrum over time [7].  As depicted in the graph, Republican ratings of government efforts against terrorism have significantly decreased from 95% during the Bush administration to 27% under Obama [7]. Democrats, while still more positive, also show a decrease from 85% to 64% in positive ratings during the same period [7]. Independents have shown a substantial drop as well [7]. ![Trends in approval ratings for government efforts against terrorism show a decline across all political parties from the Bush to Obama administrations.](image1)

Over time, there has been a shift in concerns regarding government anti-terror policies.  While concern about government restrictions on civil liberties decreased since 2013 [8],  Americans are now more concerned that government anti-terror policies haven't gone far enough to protect the country, rather than going too far in restricting civil liberties [5].  This indicates a change in public perception towards prioritizing security over civil liberties in the context of anti-terrorism efforts.

In conclusion, perceptions of government efforts to reduce terrorist threats are shaped by both age and political ideology, with older individuals and Republicans generally holding more critical views, and these perceptions have become more negative across all political affiliations over time, alongside a growing concern for stronger security measures over civil liberties.

Older Americans tend to be more critical of the government's performance in reducing terrorist threats.  For instance, a majority of those 50 and older believe the government is not performing well in this area [4]. This contrasts with younger adults (18-29 years old), where more people rate the government's performance positively [4].  This difference in perception across age groups is further supported by data showing that older Americans are more likely to give the government low marks [2].

![Image showing government's performance rating by age groups.](image4)

Looking at concerns about civil liberties versus security, younger adults under 30 are more divided, almost equally concerned about policies restricting civil liberties and policies not going far enough to protect the country [10]. However, in every other older age group, there's a stronger consensus that policies are not going far enough to ensure security, and this concern is most pronounced among those 65 and older [10].

![Image showing concern on civil liberties vs. security by age groups.](image5)

In 2015, older age groups were more critical of the government's anti-terrorism performance and expressed greater concern that policies were not strong enough to protect the country compared to younger age groups, who were more divided on both fronts.

Currently, opinions on anti-terrorism policies vary by age group, with younger adults (18-29) being split in their concerns, while older age groups, particularly those 65+, are more concerned that policies do not go far enough to protect the country [8]. ![Adults 65+ are most concerned that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough to protect the country.](image4) This is visualized in Image 4, showing the percentage breakdown across age demographics.  Over time, both Republicans and Democrats have shifted towards greater concern that anti-terrorism policies are insufficient, especially after Snowden’s disclosures in 2013 [4]. ![Republicans show a greater increase in concern that anti-terrorism policies are not far enough since 2013 compared to Democrats and Independents.](image3)  Image 3 demonstrates this trend, highlighting a more pronounced shift among Republicans. While Democrats also show increased concern, the change is less dramatic [3].  In summary, current public opinion, especially among older demographics and across political affiliations, leans towards believing anti-terrorism policies haven't gone far enough.

The public perception of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS is currently viewed negatively, but there is growing optimism regarding its eventual success.  Many believe the campaign is not progressing well, with about 58% saying it is "not too well" or "not at all well" in December 2015 [4]. This negative assessment has remained consistent over the past year ![Negative assessments of the campaign against ISIS have been consistent from Oct 2014 to Dec 2015](image4).

Despite these negative views on current progress, overall approval for the U.S. military campaign against ISIS remains high, with a majority of 64% continuing to approve in December 2015 [6].  This approval rate has been stable throughout 2015 ![Approval of the US military campaign against ISIS has been steady in 2015](image2). Furthermore, public confidence in the ultimate success of the campaign has increased. Two-thirds (66%) now believe that the U.S. and its allies will likely succeed, up from 55% in July [9]. This indicates a growing positive outlook on the final outcome of the military efforts ![Predictions of success in the campaign against ISIS increased from July to December 2015](image5).

Examining political affiliations reveals partisan divides in how the campaign is currently assessed.  As text quote [2] indicates, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to view the campaign as going at least "fairly well."  While ISIS is a significant concern across all political groups, Republicans express greater concern about it compared to Democrats and Independents, as shown in image1 ![Republicans are more concerned about ISIS than Democrats and Independents](image1).  However, when it comes to predicting ultimate success, partisan differences are less pronounced, with majorities across Republicans, Democrats, and Independents believing in the campaign's eventual success [2].

In conclusion, while current public ratings of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS remain negative, reflecting a perception of slow progress, public approval for the campaign is stable and a growing percentage believe in its ultimate success, with partisan divides mainly present in current assessments rather than predictions of final outcome.

Perceptions of Islam's propensity to encourage violence are significantly divided along political lines in America. A substantial majority of Republicans, around 68%, believe Islam is more likely to encourage violence compared to other religions, a view that has remained consistently high [9].  Conversely, only 30% of Democrats share this belief, a figure that has decreased from previous years, highlighting a growing partisan divergence [5]. This partisan gap in views has become increasingly pronounced [7].

![Line graph showing Republicans consistently perceiving Islam as more violence-encouraging than Democrats and Independents, with a widening gap between Republicans and Democrats especially in recent years.](image1)

While general public opinion is closely split on whether Islam is inherently more violent [3], this masks the deep partisan divide.  Conservative Republicans stand out as the only major group where a majority (57%) believes Muslims should face greater scrutiny in the U.S. [2]. In contrast, majorities across other ideological and political groups, including moderate and liberal Republicans, independents, and Democrats, disagree with singling out Muslims for increased scrutiny based on their religion [2], as supported by the broader public sentiment where 61% oppose additional scrutiny for Muslims [8].

![Pie chart showing 61% of Americans believe Muslims should NOT be subject to additional scrutiny, while 32% believe they SHOULD.](image2)

Interestingly, when considering government efforts to combat terrorism, a negative shift is observed across the political spectrum [6].  While Democrats remain the only partisan group where a majority (64%) still views government efforts positively, this is a significant decrease from 85% earlier in the year [6].  Republican positive assessments have plummeted to just 27%, down from 63% [6].  This indicates a widespread decline in confidence in government's counter-terrorism measures across all political affiliations.

![Line graph showing positive assessments of government efforts against terrorism declining across all groups, with Republicans showing the most significant drop and lowest positive assessment in 2015.](image3)

In summary, perceptions of Islam and violence are strongly polarized by political affiliation, with Republicans more likely to associate Islam with violence, and this partisan divide contrasts with a more broadly shared, though declining, confidence in government efforts to combat terrorism across the political spectrum.

Based on polling data, there are notable differences in how various political affiliations perceive the relationship between Islam and violence, and these perceptions have evolved over time.  A significant partisan divide exists, particularly between Republicans and Democrats, concerning whether Islam is more likely to encourage violence compared to other religions. For example, in recent surveys, a large majority of Republicans believe Islam is more violence-prone. [8]

![Line graph showing trends in perception of Islam encouraging violence among Republicans, Democrats, and Independents from 2002 to 2015.](image1)

As shown in the graph, Republicans consistently hold a higher percentage in associating Islam with violence.  Currently, about two-thirds of Republicans hold this view, a figure that has remained relatively stable since September 2014 but marks the highest point since 2002 [3].  In stark contrast, Democrats' perception has shifted, with only $30\%$ now associating Islam with violence, a decrease from $42\%$ in September 2014 [3].  This decline among Democrats is also reflected in the views of liberals, with a notable 14-point decrease in liberals associating Islam with violence since fall 2014 [2].

![Bar chart comparing public perception of party capabilities in handling terrorist threats.](image3)

Interestingly, despite these varying perceptions of Islam and violence, public opinion consistently favors the Republican party's ability to handle terrorist threats.  $46\%$ of the public believes the Republican Party can better address terrorist threats at home, compared to $34\%$ who favor the Democrats [6].

In conclusion, perceptions of Islam encouraging violence are strongly divided along political lines, with Republicans consistently more likely to associate Islam with violence, while Democrats' association has decreased.  Despite these differing views on Islam and violence, the Republican party is still perceived as more capable of handling terrorism threats by a plurality of Americans.

Perceptions regarding the scrutiny of Muslims in the U.S. vary significantly across political and demographic groups. Conservative Republicans are notably more inclined to support increased scrutiny of Muslims due to their religion, distinguishing them from other groups [3, 6].  Specifically, a majority of conservative Republicans (57%) believe Muslims should face greater scrutiny, while only 35% disagree [3].

![Conservative Republicans are more likely to support greater scrutiny of Muslims, while majorities of other groups are against it.](image3)

In contrast, liberal Democrats overwhelmingly reject the idea of subjecting Muslims to additional scrutiny, with 87% opposing such measures [2].  This view is also held by majorities of moderate and liberal Republicans (59%), independents (62%), and both conservative and moderate Democrats (67%) [6].

![Democrats are more likely to oppose additional scrutiny of Muslims compared to Republicans and Independents.](image2)

Younger adults are significantly less likely to support increased scrutiny of Muslims.  Eight-in-ten young adults (18-29) believe that scrutiny of Muslims based solely on their religion should not be part of federal counter-terrorism efforts [8, 9].  Similarly, non-whites are more likely than whites to oppose religion-based scrutiny of Muslims, with 74% of blacks and 66% of Hispanics holding this view, compared to 57% of whites [10].

![Younger adults and non-whites are more likely to oppose additional scrutiny of Muslims.](image2)

These differing views on Muslim scrutiny are linked to partisan divides on the most pressing national issues.  Republicans are more inclined to view terrorism and national security as top problems, with 41% citing these concerns, compared to fewer independents (28%) and Democrats (23%) [4]. This heightened concern about terrorism among Republicans may contribute to their greater support for Muslim scrutiny.

![Republicans are more concerned about terrorism as a national issue compared to Democrats and Independents.](image4)

These trends are also reflected in the changing views over time.  While concerns about terrorism have fluctuated, partisan divisions in threat perceptions and related policies remain evident. ![Trends in concern about terrorism among Republicans, Democrats and Independents over time.](image1)

In conclusion, opinions on whether Muslims in the U.S. should face increased scrutiny due to their religion are strongly divided along political and demographic lines, with conservative Republicans and older demographics being more supportive, while liberal Democrats, younger adults, and minority groups are more likely to oppose it, reflecting broader partisan differences in concerns about terrorism and national security.

The perception of terrorism as a critical national problem has risen significantly, accompanied by a decline in public approval of government efforts to combat it. These views also vary across political and demographic lines.

In December 2015, terrorism, including concerns about ISIS and national security, became a much more prominent issue for Americans compared to the previous year.  The percentage citing terrorism as the most important problem dramatically increased from 1% in December 2014 to 18% in December 2015, marking the largest increase among various issues. ![Terrorism as the most important problem facing the country increased from 1% in Dec 2014 to 18% in Dec 2015.](image1) This surge is also highlighted in text quote [7], stating that the proportion of Americans citing terrorism as a top problem reached its highest point since February 2003.

However, public confidence in the government's ability to reduce terrorist threats has diminished considerably.  Americans' ratings of government efforts are currently at their lowest since the aftermath of the September 11th attacks [3].  More people now believe the government is performing poorly in this area (52%) than those who think it's doing well (46%) [3]. This negative trend is not limited to one political group but is observed across the political spectrum [4, 5].  As shown in the graph, positive ratings for government anti-terrorism efforts have decreased among Republicans, Democrats, and Independents since the beginning of the year ![Government ratings on terrorism efforts have declined across party lines, especially among Republicans and Independents.](image2).

Significant partisan differences exist in how terrorism is perceived and how government efforts are evaluated [1]. Republicans are considerably more likely to consider terrorism, defense, and national security as the nation's most pressing problem compared to Democrats and Independents [1]. As evidenced by the data, a substantial 41% of Republicans mention these issues, versus 28% of independents and 23% of Democrats. ![Republicans are more likely to consider terrorism as a top problem compared to Democrats and Independents.](image3)

Age and education also contribute to differing perceptions. Older Americans (50 and older) are more inclined to believe the government is not effectively reducing the terrorist threat [2].  Similarly, individuals with less education tend to rate the government's performance negatively compared to those with postgraduate degrees [6, 10].  Data shows that older and less educated demographics express more negative views on government's anti-terrorism efforts. ![Older and less educated individuals give more negative ratings to government's anti-terrorism efforts.](image4)

In conclusion, public concern about terrorism as a major national issue has grown, while simultaneously, approval of government efforts to counter terrorism has declined across all political and demographic groups, with notable differences based on political affiliation, age, and education level.

Based on the survey results, Republicans and Democrats diverge significantly in their views on terrorism, while their perspectives on economic issues show some differences but are less pronounced.  Republicans are more inclined to consider terrorism as a critical issue facing the nation, with a notable 41% citing terrorism, defense, national security, or ISIS as top problems [5]. This is further illustrated in the survey data where terrorism is mentioned as a top problem by 24% of Republicans, compared to 16% of Democrats and 18% of Independents, highlighting a greater Republican focus on terrorism ![Republicans consider terrorism as a more significant problem than Democrats and Independents.](image1).

In contrast, while economic issues are also a concern across the political spectrum, they do not exhibit the same level of partisan divergence as terrorism.  Although the image data indicates that economic issues are considered important by both Republicans and Democrats, the difference in percentage points is less stark compared to terrorism.  For example, 7% of Republicans and 6% of Democrats cite the economy as a top problem, showing a smaller gap than for terrorism ![Economy is a concern for both Republicans and Democrats, but the partisan difference is smaller compared to terrorism.](image1).  Furthermore, while assessments of the government's efforts to combat terrorism have become more negative across all political groups, Republicans have shown a sharper decline in positive ratings [6].  In fact, positive ratings of government efforts among Republicans have drastically fallen from 59% in January to just 18% currently [4]. This negative shift is visually represented in the graph, where Republican ratings plummet significantly over time, particularly under the Obama administration ![Republican ratings of government efforts on terrorism show a sharp decline, especially during Obama's presidency.](image2).

Moreover, Republicans are more inclined to believe that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough, with over 70% expressing this concern [2]. This suggests a stronger stance among Republicans for more robust anti-terrorism measures compared to Democrats.  However, it’s also important to note that while Republicans prioritize terrorism more, Democrats are more likely to point to issues like partisan gridlock and division as major problems [7].

In summary, Republicans prioritize terrorism as a more critical national problem and express greater dissatisfaction with government efforts in this area compared to Democrats, while economic issues are a shared concern but do not reveal as stark partisan differences.

Views on the importance of terrorism and the evaluation of government efforts to counter it are significantly divided along political lines. Republicans are more likely to consider terrorism a critical national issue compared to Democrats and Independents [6].  For example, 41% of Republicans cite terrorism, defense, national security, or ISIS as the nation's most pressing problem, while fewer Independents (28%) and Democrats (23%) share this concern [6].

This difference in perceived importance is mirrored in their evaluations of the government's anti-terrorism efforts.  Democrats are more positive, with a majority (64%) believing the government is doing at least fairly well in reducing the terrorist threat [4].

![Democrats are more likely to rate government's effort to combat terrorism as very/fairly well, at 64 percent.](image2)

In stark contrast, Republicans are considerably more critical.  Only 27% of Republicans think the government is doing well in this area [4].  This partisan gap is further highlighted when comparing trends over time.  Republicans' positive assessments of government efforts have significantly decreased, while Democrats' ratings, although also down from previous highs, remain much more favorable [4].

![Republican ratings of government efforts against terrorism have dropped significantly while Democrat ratings remain higher.](image4)

Furthermore, when considering the most important problem facing the nation, terrorism ranks higher among Republicans (24%) than Democrats (16%) and Independents (18%), reinforcing the idea that Republicans prioritize terrorism to a greater extent [image3].

![Terrorism is mentioned as a more important problem by Republicans (24%) than Democrats (16%) or Independents (18%).](image3)

In conclusion, political affiliation strongly influences the perception of terrorism's importance and the evaluation of government actions against it, with Republicans prioritizing terrorism more and expressing greater dissatisfaction with government efforts compared to Democrats.

Independent voters hold nuanced views on government regulation and economic fairness, differing in significant ways from both Democrats and Republicans. While independents are overall divided on government regulation of business [7], and about half think government regulation is necessary to protect public interest, and another approximate half think it does more harm than good, their opinions diverge when compared to partisans.

![Independent voters are divided on whether government regulation is necessary or harmful, with roughly equal percentages holding each view.](image1)

As shown in the image, Democrats overwhelmingly believe government regulation is necessary to protect public interest, while Republicans largely believe it does more harm than good. In contrast, independents are split, indicating a less defined stance on this issue compared to the strong partisan opinions.

Regarding economic fairness, a majority of independents believe that the U.S. economic system unfairly favors powerful interests [3]. This view is shared by large majorities of Democrats and Democratic leaners [3].

![A significant majority of independent voters believe the U.S. economic system unfairly favors powerful interests.](image4)

However, as seen in the image, this perspective is less pronounced among Republicans, with a majority of Republicans believing the economic system is generally fair [6].  While GOP leaners are more divided on this issue [6], the overall trend shows a partisan divide, with independents aligning more closely with Democrats in their perception of economic unfairness compared to Republicans.

In conclusion, independent voters are more divided on government regulation compared to the clear stances of Democrats and Republicans, but they tend to align more with Democrats in believing that the U.S. economic system unfairly favors powerful interests, contrasting with the Republican view of a generally fair system.

Over time, the percentage of independents holding unfavorable views towards both major parties has seen fluctuations. While at one point in 2015, over a third of independents held negative views of both parties [9], this figure has since decreased [9]. However, examining the broader trend from 1994 to 2018, the proportion of independents favorable to both parties has declined, while those favorable to one party and unfavorable to the other has increased, suggesting a move away from neutral perspectives. ![The percentage of independents favorable to both parties decreased from 32% in 1994 to 17% in 2018, whereas those unfavorable to both parties fluctuated and stood at 12% in 2018.](image1)

Notably, independents who do not lean towards a party are more inclined to have unfavorable opinions of both parties compared to those who lean [8]. Indeed, 37% of non-leaning independents express unfavorable views towards both parties [2].  Conversely, independents who lean towards a party often demonstrate partisan characteristics, mirroring the negative views of the opposing party held by party identifiers [10].  Intense dislike of the opposing party has also risen among independents who lean towards either the Republican or Democratic parties [7].  As illustrated, non-leaning independents are the subgroup most likely to view both parties unfavorably, while leaners typically express unfavorable views towards one party, aligning with their leaning [image3].

In conclusion, while the proportion of independents with unfavorable views of both parties has recently decreased, non-leaning independents remain the most likely subgroup to hold negative views towards both major U.S. political parties, whereas leaners tend to mirror partisan animosity towards the opposing party.

Over the past two decades, negative views of the opposing party have significantly increased among both Republicans and Democrats, and this trend is also evident among independents who lean towards either party [8].  This increase is substantial; for Democratic-leaning independents, very unfavorable opinions of the Republican Party have more than quadrupled from 1994 to 2018, rising from 8% to 37%. A similar increase is seen among Republican leaners' views of the Democratic Party, with very unfavorable opinions growing from 15% to 39% in the same period [2].

![The graph illustrates the increasing unfavorable views of the Republican and Democratic parties among Democrats, Republicans, and leaning independents from 1994 to 2018.](image4)

Currently, high percentages of both Democrats and Republicans hold unfavorable views of the opposing party.  Specifically, 87% of Republicans view the Democratic Party unfavorably, and 88% of Democrats view the Republican Party unfavorably [3].  Among those who lean towards a party, the sentiment is similar, with 81% of Republican leaners and 84% of Democratic leaners viewing the opposing party negatively [3].

![This bar chart shows the percentage of different political groups who are favorable to one party and unfavorable to the other, favorable to both parties, and unfavorable to both parties.](image1)

Independents present a more varied picture.  A notable portion of independents who do not lean towards either party, 37%, hold unfavorable opinions of *both* parties [6].  In contrast, only 28% of all independents have an unfavorable opinion of both parties, which is still higher than Republicans (10%) or Democrats (9%) [4].  However, independents who do not lean are also the most likely group to have favorable opinions of both parties, with 22% holding such views [6].

![This bar chart shows the percentage of different political groups who are favorable to one party and unfavorable to the other, favorable to both parties, and unfavorable to both parties.](image1)

While a considerable number of independents view both parties unfavorably, this share has declined in recent years from a high of 36% in 2015 [9].  Independents who do not lean towards a party remain more inclined to have negative views of both parties compared to those who lean towards a party [10].

In summary, unfavorable views towards opposing political parties have risen significantly over the past two decades across all political affiliations, with current data indicating high levels of unfavorable opinions among partisans and leaners, while independents show a more diverse range of views, with non-leaning independents being more likely to dislike both parties but also more likely to like both.

The perceptions of Republicans and Democrats diverge significantly when it comes to China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak.  Republicans are notably more critical of China's response to the pandemic compared to Democrats [4].  As text quote [4] indicates,  "Republicans and Republican- leaning independents are significantly more likely than Democrats and Democratic leaners to have  a  very  unfavorable view of China, to criticize the Chinese government’s role in the global  pandemic".  This partisan divide is also evident in the assessment of China's handling of the coronavirus, where a larger percentage of Republicans believe China has done a bad job [10].

![82% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents think China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus, compared to 54% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents.](image1)

As shown in image1,  $82\%$ of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe China has handled the coronavirus outbreak badly, in stark contrast to the $54\%$ of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents who share this view.  Furthermore, Republicans are more inclined to attribute blame to China for the global spread of the virus.  A substantial $73\%$ of Republicans believe China's initial actions significantly contributed to the virus's global dissemination, compared to a smaller $38\%$ of Democrats holding the same belief [5].

![51% of Americans believe China's initial handling contributed a great deal to the global spread of the virus.](image4)

Image4 illustrates that overall, a majority of Americans attribute a great deal of blame to China's initial handling for the global spread, with $51\%$ believing it contributed a great deal. However, this percentage is significantly higher among Republicans as indicated in text quote [5]. This difference in perception extends to policy preferences concerning U.S.-China relations. Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to prioritize holding China accountable for its role in the outbreak, even if it negatively impacts economic relations [9].

![50% of Americans think the U.S. should hold China responsible for the outbreak, even if it means worsening economic relations.](image5)

Image5 highlights that while half of Americans believe the U.S. should hold China responsible despite potential economic repercussions, this view is much stronger within the Republican base, as detailed in text quote [9]. In summary, Republicans hold a more critical view of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak and are more inclined to prioritize holding China accountable, even at the expense of U.S.-China economic relations, compared to Democrats.

Americans hold differing views on China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly along political lines. Republicans are significantly more critical of China's response compared to Democrats [1, 10].  For instance, a large majority of Republicans, 82%, believe China has done a bad job handling the coronavirus, while only 54% of Democrats share this view [10].  ![82% of Republicans think China did a bad job handling COVID-19, compared to 54% of Democrats.](image4)  This partisan gap is also evident in the belief that China's initial handling in Wuhan contributed "a great deal" to the global spread, with 73% of Republicans agreeing, versus 38% of Democrats [7].

Furthermore, a substantial portion of Americans believe that the U.S. should hold China accountable for its role in the coronavirus outbreak, even if it damages economic relations.  Half of Americans support this stance, while 38% prioritize strong U.S.-China relations even if it means overlooking China's role [3].  ![50% of Americans believe the U.S. should hold China responsible for the outbreak even if it worsens economic relations.](image1) Republicans are twice as likely as Democrats to favor holding China responsible at the cost of economic relations, with 71% of Republicans and 37% of Democrats in agreement [3].

Over time, negative perceptions of China have increased across the political spectrum [4].  As shown in the graph, unfavorable views of China among both Republicans and Democrats have risen sharply between 2019 and 2020. ![Line graph shows the sharp increase of unfavorable views on China among both Republicans and Democrats from 2019 to 2020.](image2)  In 2020, a majority of Republicans (63%) and a large majority of Democrats (73%) believe bilateral economic ties with China are bad, representing a 15-point and 12-point increase, respectively, from the previous year [4].  This overall negative shift is also reflected in the increased percentage of Americans who view China's handling of the outbreak as "bad", rising from 53% in 2019 to 68% in 2020 [8]. ![Line graph depicting the increase of negative views on China's COVID handling from 2019 to 2020.](image3)

In conclusion, Republicans are considerably more critical of China's COVID-19 response than Democrats, and negative perceptions of China have grown significantly among both groups over time.

Americans hold critical views regarding China's role in the coronavirus outbreak, with a significant majority attributing blame to the Chinese government's initial response in Wuhan [1, 4, 6, 9]. Around three-quarters of Americans believe that China's early handling of the pandemic significantly contributed to its global spread [4]. This perception is further illustrated in the distribution of blame, where a substantial portion believes China is to blame for the global spread of the virus.  ![51% of Americans believe China is greatly to blame for the global spread of the coronavirus.](image2)

There is a notable partisan divide in these views. Republicans are considerably more critical of China's handling of the outbreak compared to Democrats [4, 8].  A large majority of Republicans believe China did a bad job handling the coronavirus. ![82% of Republicans think China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak.](image3) This contrasts with Democrats, although a majority still hold a negative view, the percentage is lower. [8]

Furthermore, half of Americans believe that the U.S. should hold China accountable for its role in the pandemic, even if it negatively impacts economic relations [5, 7].  This is reflected in public opinion where half of the respondents support holding China responsible. ![50% of Americans believe the U.S. should hold China responsible for the coronavirus outbreak.](image1)  However, a considerable portion prioritizes maintaining strong U.S.-China relations, even if it means overlooking China's role in the outbreak [7].

Over time, there's a discernible trend towards a more critical stance on China.  Negative views on China's handling of the coronavirus have increased from 2019 to 2020. ![Negative views on China's handling of the coronavirus increased from 2019 to 2020, while positive views decreased.](image5)  This shift aligns with a broader trend of Americans favoring a tougher approach to U.S.-China relations, as opposed to building stronger ties. ![More Americans in 2020 prefer to get tougher with China compared to building a stronger relationship.](image4)

In conclusion, Americans largely view China unfavorably regarding its role in the coronavirus outbreak and increasingly favor a tougher stance in U.S.-China relations, with these views being more pronounced among Republicans and reflecting a growing critical trend over time.

American perceptions of China have significantly worsened, particularly regarding China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and the overall U.S.-China relationship.  A large majority of Americans hold unfavorable views of China, a sentiment that has intensified in recent years [5].

![Unfavorable views of China have been increasing, reaching 73% in recent surveys.](image4)

This increasing negativity is closely linked to how Americans perceive China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak.  Most Americans believe China dealt poorly with COVID-19 [1], and a substantial majority, around two-thirds, explicitly state that China did a bad job in managing the outbreak [7].

![64% of Americans think China did a bad job handling the coronavirus outbreak.](image3)

Furthermore, a considerable number of Americans attribute blame to the Chinese government for the global spread of the virus. Approximately three-quarters of Americans place a great deal or fair amount of blame on China's initial response in Wuhan [7].

![78% of Americans place a great deal or fair amount of blame on China's initial handling of COVID-19.](image5)

This perception of mishandling and blame significantly influences overall negative views towards China [9].  While there's a desire to hold China accountable for its role in the outbreak [2, 10], Americans are somewhat divided on whether to prioritize getting tough on China economically or maintaining strong economic ties [2].  However, there's a growing sense that current economic ties between the U.S. and China are in poor condition [8].

![Democrats and Republicans have different views on holding China responsible and getting tougher on China.](image1)

In conclusion, American perceptions of China have evolved to become increasingly negative, largely driven by views of China's poor handling of COVID-19 and the blame attributed to them for the pandemic's global spread, impacting the outlook on U.S.-China relations and economic ties.

The perception of China among Americans has become increasingly negative in recent years [9].  Unfavorable views of China have reached a historic high, with 73% of Americans holding this opinion, a significant increase of 26 percentage points since 2018 [2]. This negative shift has been particularly sharp in recent months [5].  ![73% of Americans have an unfavorable view of China overall.](image4)

Older Americans express more negative views towards China compared to younger age groups [3], [10].  Those aged 50 and older are substantially more negative in their views of China, with 81% holding unfavorable opinions, compared to 56% of those under 30 [3].  ![Breakdown of favorable and unfavorable views of China across age groups.](image1)  Furthermore, older Americans are more likely to see China as an enemy, while younger Americans are more inclined to view China as a partner [8].

There's a notable partisan divide in these perceptions, with Republicans consistently holding more unfavorable views of China than Democrats [6].  Currently, 83% of Republicans have an unfavorable view, compared to 68% of Democrats [6].  ![Comparison of unfavorable views of China between Republican and Democrats.](image2) This partisan gap has re-emerged recently [1], and the trend of unfavorable views has increased for both Republicans and Democrats over time, with a steeper rise among Republicans in recent years  ![Trend line showing increase in unfavorable views of China among Republicans and Democrats since 2005.](image5).

In conclusion, negative perceptions of China have increased significantly across all demographics in the U.S., with older Americans and Republicans consistently expressing the most unfavorable views.

The unfavorable view of China has significantly increased among Americans in recent years [2, 10].  As shown in the line chart, negative sentiment has risen notably since around 2018, reaching historic highs [2].

![Line chart illustrates the trend of unfavorable views of China among Republicans and Democrats from 2005 to 2020, showing a sharp increase in recent years for both groups.](image1)

While both Republicans and Democrats are becoming more negative, Republicans consistently hold more unfavorable views toward China than Democrats [1, 7].  In fact, Republicans are significantly more likely to express a *very* unfavorable view (54%) compared to Democrats (35%) [7].  The gap between the two parties regarding unfavorable views has also widened recently [3].

![Bar chart shows that 83% of Republicans and 68% of Democrats have unfavorable views of China.](image2)

Analyzing age groups, older Americans (ages 50 and older) express substantially more negative views of China (81%) than younger age groups, such as those aged 18-29 (56%) [9].  This difference is also visualized in the line chart which shows that older age groups consistently have higher unfavorable views over time [9].

![Line chart displays unfavorable views of China across age groups (18-29, 30-49, 50 and older) from 2005 to 2020, indicating older age groups consistently show higher unfavorable views.](image4)

In conclusion, unfavorable views of China have evolved to historic highs across all demographics in the U.S., with Republicans and older Americans consistently expressing the most negative sentiments, and the partisan gap widening recently.

Views on China are increasingly negative among Americans, reaching historic highs in recent surveys [4, 10].  This negative sentiment is not uniform across all demographics, showing notable differences based on age and political affiliation.

Older Americans consistently hold more unfavorable views of China compared to younger age groups [6]. For instance, Americans aged 50 and older are substantially more negative towards China than those aged 30-49 or under 30 [6]. This is further illustrated in the data, where the percentage of unfavorable views increases with age.  ![Unfavorable views of China increase with age](image3). Older Americans are also significantly more likely to perceive China as an enemy, while younger Americans are more inclined to see China as a partner [7].

![Percentage of Americans with "bad" views of China, broken down by age and political affiliation](image1)

Politically, Republicans consistently express more negative views of China than Democrats [1]. A significant gap exists between the two parties, with Republicans holding considerably more unfavorable opinions [1].  This partisan divide has widened recently, as negative views among Republicans have increased more sharply than among Democrats in recent months [2, 9].  As seen in the graph, both Republican and Democrat unfavorable views have been on an upward trend, but the rate of increase is higher for Republicans, leading to a larger gap between the parties over time. ![Trend of unfavorable views of China among Republicans and Democrats from 2005 to 2020](image2).

Americans' views on China are increasingly negative, with older Republicans holding the most unfavorable opinions, and this negative sentiment has grown significantly across age groups and political affiliations over time.

Negative opinions of China have significantly increased in the United States across different demographics in recent years [8].  Older Americans, particularly those aged 50 and above, consistently hold more unfavorable views of China compared to younger age groups, and this negative sentiment has intensified recently [3, 5]. For example, in July 2020, 81% of Americans aged 50 and older had an unfavorable view of China, compared to 56% of those under 30. ![Unfavorable views of China are higher for older age groups compared to younger age groups](image2).  This trend of increasing negativity among older Americans is also evident over time, as shown in data spanning from 2005 to 2020. ![Unfavorable views of China over time for different age groups](image3).

Furthermore, political affiliation plays a crucial role, with Republicans consistently expressing more negative opinions of China than Democrats [6]. This partisan gap has been a feature for the last 15 years and has widened recently as negative views have increased more sharply among Republicans [1, 9]. In July 2020, 83% of Republicans held an unfavorable view compared to 68% of Democrats. ![Unfavorable views of China are higher for Republicans compared to Democrats](image2).  The trend of unfavorable views over time also shows that while both groups have become more negative, the increase is more pronounced among Republicans. ![Unfavorable views of China over time for Republicans and Democrats](image5). These findings are based on surveys conducted by the Pew Research Center, highlighting a growing negative perception of China across various segments of the US population [4, 10]. In conclusion, negative opinions of China have increased notably across all age groups and political affiliations in the US, with older Americans and Republicans exhibiting the most significant rise in unfavorable views and a widening partisan divide.

Americans' perceptions of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic vary across age groups and political affiliations, building upon existing unfavorable views of China.  A significant majority of Americans hold a negative opinion of China [1].  ![Bar chart showing 73% of total respondents have unfavorable view of China.](image5)  This negative sentiment is further reflected in views on China's pandemic response, with approximately two-thirds of Americans believing China did a bad job handling the coronavirus outbreak [3].  ![Bar chart showing 64% of total respondents think China did a bad job handling the coronavirus.](image3)  Around three-quarters also believe China's initial response in Wuhan significantly contributed to the global spread of the virus [6]. ![Bar chart indicating 78% of respondents believe China's initial handling contributed a great deal or a fair amount to the spread.](image4)

Age plays a notable role in these perceptions. Older Americans, those aged 50 and above, exhibit substantially more negative views of China (81%) compared to younger demographics [7].  ![Line chart showing unfavorable views of China by age group over time, with older age groups consistently more negative.](image2)  Similarly, older individuals are more critical of China's pandemic response, with 73% of those 50 and older finding fault, compared to lower percentages in younger age groups [9].  ![Bar chart showing 73% of respondents aged 50+ think China did a bad job handling the coronavirus.](image3)

Political affiliation is another key differentiator. Republicans consistently hold more unfavorable views of China than Democrats [5].  ![Line chart showing unfavorable views of China by party affiliation over time, with Republicans consistently more negative.](image1)  This partisan gap is also evident in perceptions of China's pandemic handling. A significantly larger percentage of Republicans (82%) believe China did a bad job with the coronavirus compared to Democrats (54%) [9].  ![Bar chart showing 82% of Republican/Lean Republican respondents think China did a bad job handling the coronavirus compared to 54% of Democrat/Lean Democrat respondents.](image3)  Furthermore, Republicans are much more likely to believe China's early actions greatly contributed to the global spread of the virus [6]. Based on the provided quotes, perceptions of China's handling of COVID-19 significantly vary across age groups and political affiliations. Based on political affiliations in the U.S., Republicans and Democrats prioritize different foreign policy partners. However, views on Germany are similar across party lines, with both ranking Germany as a significant foreign policy partner [8].

In terms of cooperation, Democrats are more inclined towards greater cooperation with Germany compared to Republicans [3].  About two-thirds of Democrats favor close ties with Germany, while Republicans show slightly less preference [4].  Conversely, Republicans are more inclined to prefer closer relations with Russia than Democrats [4].  However, when it comes to Germany as a foreign policy partner, both Democrats and Republicans are about equally likely to name Germany as a top partner [6].

In Germany, political affiliation also plays a role in foreign policy preferences. Supporters of CDU/CSU are more inclined to desire greater cooperation with the U.S. compared to those who support the Greens and the SPD [3].  German supporters of CDU/CSU, SPD and Greens commonly identify France as a primary foreign policy partner, followed by the U.S. [9].

![Democrats in the U.S. and CDU/CSU supporters in Germany are more likely to want greater cooperation.](image5)

Specifically, 66% of Germans want more cooperation with Russia, while only 35% of Americans share this view ![Germans are more likely to want more cooperation with Russia than Americans](image1).

Political party affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany further shape these preferences. In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are more willing to pursue greater cooperation with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD [9]. However, when it comes to cooperation with China, there is more alignment between Americans and Germans, with similar majorities in both countries expressing a desire for increased collaboration [7].

In conclusion, Germans are more supportive of increased cooperation with Russia than Americans, and political party affiliations in both nations influence these preferences, although there's a common interest in greater cooperation with China.

Political party preferences in both the U.S. and Germany significantly shape attitudes toward international cooperation.  In the U.S., Democrats are more inclined to seek greater cooperation with Germany compared to Republicans, indicating a partisan divide in foreign policy priorities [1].  Similarly, within Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are more eager for stronger cooperation with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD, highlighting ideological variations in foreign policy orientation within Germany as well [1].

![Germans from CDU/CSU are more likely to consider relationship with U.S. as good than supporters of Greens and SPD; Democrats in the U.S. are more likely to consider relationship with Germany as good than Republicans](image1)

This partisan divergence extends to views on Russia. Interestingly, when considering cooperation with Russia, Germans overall are more likely than Americans to desire increased collaboration, but within both nations, there are partisan and regional differences [3]. ![Americans and Germans show different level of desire for more cooperation with Russia and China](image3)

Furthermore, when faced with a choice between close relationships with Germany or Russia, Americans overwhelmingly favor Germany. However, among Germans, the preference for either the U.S. or Russia is less pronounced, with a notable portion open to close ties with both [8]. Political party preferences in the U.S. and Germany strongly influence attitudes toward cooperation with countries like Russia and China.

Based on political affiliations, both in the U.S. and Germany, there are observable differences in attitudes toward cooperation with Russia. This partisan divide is also evident when considering close relationships, where 31% of Republicans favor close ties with Russia, versus 21% of Democrats [4].

In Germany, similar ideological trends are observed, with those on the right of the political spectrum being more inclined to view Russia favorably compared to those on the left [9]. This is further illustrated by the fact that nearly four-in-ten East Germans prefer close ties with Russia, whereas only 23% favor the U.S.  Conversely, West Germans are twice as likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. than with Russia [7].

In both the U.S. and Germany, political affiliations significantly shape attitudes towards cooperation with Russia, with right-leaning groups and those in former East Germany showing more favorable views.

Americans and Germans hold contrasting perspectives on the world’s leading economic power. Furthermore, opinions diverge regarding international entities such as the European Union. Germans generally hold more positive views of the EU compared to Americans [8]. In summary, Germans are more inclined to see China as the leading economic power and hold more favorable views of the EU compared to Americans.

Americans and Germans exhibit notable differences in their perceptions of international organizations and economic power, influenced by various factors such as ideology and geographical location [1]. Americans and Germans have different perspectives on the necessity of military force.  A significant majority of Americans believe that military force is sometimes necessary to maintain order in the world, while only about half of Germans agree [4].  For instance, approximately eight-in-ten Americans find the use of force justifiable in certain situations, compared to roughly half of Germans who share this view [4].  This divergence is further highlighted when considering NATO obligations; while six-in-ten Americans believe in using military force to defend a NATO ally against a potential Russian attack, an equal proportion of Germans disagree [7].  This difference in opinion is visually represented in ![Germans are less likely than Americans to agree on using military force to defend a NATO ally.](image3), which shows that 60% of Americans believe in defending a NATO ally, compared to only 34% of Germans.

Regarding defense spending, opinions also differ.  While half of Americans believe that European allies should maintain their current defense spending levels, this represents a shift from 2017 when more Americans favored increased spending by European allies [1].  Germans are divided on their own country's defense spending, with roughly equal proportions supporting either maintaining or increasing current levels [5].  This is further illustrated in ![Americans are increasingly content with current defense spending levels of European allies, while Germans are divided on their own defense spending.](image1), which shows the trends in opinions on defense spending in both countries over recent years.

However, younger generations in both the U.S. and Germany hold more positive views of the U.S.-German relationship compared to older generations [2, 8].  Specifically, in the U.S., a higher percentage of 18- to 29-year-olds view the relationship as good compared to those 65 and older; a similar trend is observed in Germany [2].  This age-based difference in perception is visualized in ![Younger people in both US and Germany have more positive views on US-Germany relationship.](image4), which shows the percentage of different age groups in both countries that view the US-German relationship as good.

In conclusion, Americans are generally more inclined to see military force as necessary and are shifting towards maintaining current defense spending levels among European allies, while Germans are more hesitant about military force and divided on increasing their own defense spending; however, younger people in both nations share a more positive outlook on the U.S.-German relationship.

Americans and Germans show different opinions on defense spending, and these opinions have shifted over time with partisan divides within each nation.  While a notable portion of Americans believe European allies should increase defense spending, Germans are less convinced. The trend of decreasing support for increased defense spending among both Republicans and Democrats in the U.S. is shown in the graph from 2017 to 2019 ![The percentage of both Republicans and Democrats who think European allies should increase defense spending has decreased from 2017 to 2019.](image2).  In Germany, partisan gaps are also present, with CDU/CSU supporters being more in favor of increased defense spending compared to Greens supporters, while SPD members fall in the middle [1]. Americans and Germans show diverging trends in their views on national defense spending between 2017 and 2019. In the U.S., there has been a decrease in the percentage of Americans who believe European allies should increase their defense spending [4].  ![Americans increasingly believe European allies should keep defense spending the same rather than increase it, from 2017 to 2019.](image1) This is shown in the shift from 45% in 2017 to 35% in 2019 who felt European allies should increase spending, while those who believe spending should remain the same increased from 37% to 50% during the same period.

Within the U.S., partisan divides are evident. In Germany, public opinion on their *own* defense spending is divided [10]. Partisan differences are also present in Germany. Supporters of CDU/CSU are more in favor of increasing defense spending compared to supporters of the Greens, who are more skeptical [9]. ![CDU/CSU supporters are more likely to favor increased defense spending compared to SPD and Greens supporters.](image5)

In summary, American views on European defense spending have softened towards maintaining current levels, with partisan divides, while German views on their own defense spending have become more divided, also showing partisan variations.

In both the U.S. and Germany, political affiliations significantly shape opinions on increasing defense spending. Political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany strongly influence opinions on increasing defense spending, with clear partisan divides and some shifts in these opinions over time.

Age differences in Germany and political affiliations in the U.S. reveal contrasting perspectives on the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany and preferred foreign policy partners. In Germany, older individuals are more likely to view U.S. military bases as vital for their national security, whereas younger generations are more skeptical.  Specifically, approximately six-in-ten Germans aged 18 to 29 believe that U.S. military bases in Germany do not contribute to German national security, while a contrasting 61% of those 65 and older hold the opposite view, considering these bases important for Germany's defense [9]. ![Older Germans are more likely to consider US military bases important for national security, while younger Germans tend to disagree.](image5) This generational divide is evident in the broader German population, where about half see U.S. military bases as important for national security, and a substantial 45% disagree [8]. In contrast, across the Atlantic, the American perspective differs significantly, with a strong consensus among both Republicans and Democrats regarding the importance of the U.S. military presence in Germany [10]. ![Americans are more likely than Germans to view US military bases as important for German security.](image3)

In the U.S., political affiliation influences the selection of top foreign policy partners. While both Republicans and Democrats prioritize the UK, notable differences emerge with other countries. Republicans show a stronger inclination towards Israel as a key partner, while Democrats place greater emphasis on Canada and Mexico [4]. ![Republicans favor Israel as a foreign policy partner more than Democrats, while Democrats favor Canada and Mexico more than Republicans.](image4)  Despite these partisan variations in partner preferences, views on Germany are consistent across political divides in the U.S., with both Republicans and Democrats ranking Germany around fifth in importance as a foreign policy partner [4, 7].

In conclusion, age in Germany creates a divide in perceiving the importance of US military bases, with younger Germans being more doubtful, whereas in the U.S., political affiliation shapes preferences for foreign policy partners, though Germany's importance is similarly recognized across parties.

Based on political affiliation, Republicans are more inclined to prioritize domestic issues over global engagement, while Democrats are more open to international cooperation.  For instance, a significant majority of Republicans advocate for the U.S. to concentrate on its own challenges and allow other nations to manage independently [5]. This contrasts with Democrats, a majority of whom believe the U.S. should assist other countries in addressing their problems [8].  ![Republicans are more likely to think the US should deal with its own problems and let other countries deal as best they can, while Democrats are more split.](image3)  Over time, Republicans increasingly believe the U.S. is doing too much to solve world problems. ![The percentage of Republicans who believe the US is doing “too much” to solve world problems has increased over time, especially in 2020.](image5)

Education also plays a role, with higher education levels correlating with greater support for U.S. involvement in international issues.  Americans with postgraduate degrees are more inclined to support the U.S. helping other nations compared to those with lower educational attainment [10]. Regarding views on handling international issues, specifically the pandemic, partisan lines are sharply drawn in evaluations of the U.S.'s response.  A large majority of Democrats are critical of the U.S.’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak, whereas a similar proportion of Republicans praise it [9].  ![Democrats are more likely to rate the U.S. coronavirus response as only fair or poor, while Republicans are more likely to rate it as good or excellent.](image4)  Conversely, when evaluating China's handling of the virus, while majorities across party lines express criticism, Republicans are significantly more likely to hold this negative view than Democrats [6].  ![Republicans are more likely to rate China's coronavirus response as only fair or poor compared to Democrats.](image1)

Interestingly, education has a limited impact on perceptions of China's pandemic response, with majorities across all educational levels critical of China's handling [1]. In conclusion, political affiliation and education level are significant factors shaping views on U.S. global engagement and the handling of international issues, with Republicans and those with lower education levels favoring domestic focus, while Democrats and those with higher education levels are more supportive of international cooperation and critical of the U.S.'s pandemic response.

Americans' perceptions of the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic are significantly shaped by their political affiliations. ![Republicans are more likely to rate the U.S.'s COVID-19 response as good or excellent.](image4)

As shown in the image, there is a 44-percentage-point gap between Republicans and Democrats in their assessment of the U.S.'s response, with Republicans viewing it much more positively.

Similarly, partisan lines influence opinions on China's handling of the pandemic. While a majority across party lines agree that China did not handle the outbreak well, Republicans are significantly more critical than Democrats [9]. Conservative Republicans are particularly likely to hold a negative view of China's response [9].

![Democrats are more critical of the U.S.'s COVID-19 response than Republicans, while Republicans are more critical of China's response than Democrats.](image2)

This image further illustrates that Democrats are less critical of China’s response compared to Republicans, highlighting the partisan polarization in evaluating both countries' pandemic responses.

In conclusion, political affiliation is a strong determinant in how Americans perceive the effectiveness of the U.S.'s and China's responses to the COVID-19 pandemic, leading to significantly divergent evaluations along partisan lines.

The perception of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries in handling the coronavirus outbreak is significantly divided along political lines.  Democrats are much more inclined to believe that the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, with liberal Democrats leading this view [5, 6].  In stark contrast, conservative Republicans are far less likely to share this belief [5].

For instance, 67% of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, compared to only 25% of conservative Republicans [5]. This partisan gap is evident in the overall views as well, where 60% of Democrats versus only 28% of Republicans think the U.S. can learn a great deal internationally [6].

This partisan divide extends to the evaluation of the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic.  Those who believe the U.S. can learn from foreign countries tend to have a less positive assessment of the U.S.'s performance [1].  Specifically, only 44% of those who think the U.S. can learn from abroad rate the country's handling as excellent or good, while 63% of those who think the U.S. cannot learn much from overseas give positive ratings [1]. This difference in perception is also reflected in the overall evaluation of the U.S.'s handling of the coronavirus outbreak across different demographics.

![The bar chart illustrates that 70% of Republicans and Republican leaners believe the US handling of the coronavirus outbreak is only fair or poor, compared to 36% of Democrats and Democrat leaners who share this negative assessment.](image1)

Furthermore, trust in international organizations such as the WHO and EU also exhibits partisan polarization.  Liberal Democrats show a high degree of trust in information from the WHO, with 86% trusting it at least a fair amount, whereas only 27% of conservative Republicans share this level of trust [10].  Similar, although somewhat smaller, partisan divisions exist in trust towards information from the EU [10].

![The horizontal dot plot compares the trust levels in information from WHO, EU, and Chinese government across different political groups, showing a significant partisan gap especially for WHO and EU.](image2)

In summary, political affiliation strongly influences the perception of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries in pandemic management, which in turn correlates with the evaluation of the U.S.'s handling of the outbreak and trust in international organizations like the WHO and EU.  Democrats are more likely to believe in learning from abroad and trust international organizations, while Republicans are less inclined to both.

Views on the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China are significantly shaped by political affiliation.  Republicans are considerably more inclined to believe that China's global influence will decrease due to the coronavirus outbreak, with roughly six in ten holding this view, compared to only 40% of Democrats [1]. This partisan divide is further emphasized in perceptions of U.S. influence, where Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to anticipate a strengthening of U.S. international influence post-crisis [3]. Conversely, Democrats are four times more likely to foresee a weakening of American influence [3].  ![Republicans are more likely to think the U.S. influence will increase or stay the same, while Democrats are more likely to think it will decrease.](image1)

Education level also plays a role, particularly in views about U.S. influence.  Americans with higher education levels are more inclined to anticipate a decline in the country's global influence [10]. For instance, 45% of those with postgraduate degrees believe U.S. influence will recede [10], a perspective also reflected in image data.

Overall, when comparing the anticipated influence of different global powers, half of Americans believe China's influence will diminish, while fewer expect this for the U.S. or the EU [2, 6].  ![Half of Americans think China will have less influence, while about 30% think the U.S. and EU will have less influence.](image3)

In summary, political affiliation and education level are key factors in shaping views on the future global influence of the U.S., EU, and China, with partisan divides being especially pronounced in opinions regarding China and the U.S., and education level correlating with perspectives on U.S. influence.

Predictions on the future global influence of the U.S. and China following the coronavirus outbreak vary significantly across different demographic and political groups.  Americans are divided along partisan lines regarding the U.S.'s future global influence, with Republicans more optimistic about its strengthening and Democrats more inclined to foresee a weakening [1].  This partisan divide is evident in the different expectations based on political affiliation.

![Republicans are more likely to believe US influence will increase while Democrats are more likely to believe it will decrease.](image1)

Furthermore, education level also plays a role, as individuals with higher education are more likely to anticipate a decline in U.S. global influence [9].  Regarding China, a considerable portion of Americans anticipate a decrease in its global influence after the pandemic [10].

![A majority of Americans believe China's influence will decrease after the coronavirus outbreak.](image2)

However, similar to the U.S., partisan divisions exist in predictions for China's global influence. Republicans are more inclined to believe China's influence will diminish, while Democrats are less convinced [4].  Age is another differentiating factor, with older Americans being more likely to expect a decrease in China's global clout compared to younger adults [4].  These partisan and age-related differences mirror existing attitudes where older Americans and Republicans often hold more negative views of China [7].  Overall, predictions for both U.S. and China's global influence after the coronavirus outbreak are shaped by political and demographic factors, with partisan affiliation and age being particularly significant dividers in these expectations.

Americans hold largely unfavorable views regarding China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak.  Nearly two-thirds of Americans believe China did not handle the coronavirus outbreak effectively, with a significant portion, $37\%$, describing their performance as poor [3].

![China is rated poorly on handling coronavirus outbreak by Americans](image5)

This negative perception is further compounded by a lack of trust in the information originating from the Chinese government regarding the coronavirus [1].  A considerable percentage of Americans, specifically half, anticipate a decline in China's global influence following the pandemic [2]. This sentiment is visually represented, with $50\%$ of Americans believing China will have less influence in world affairs post-pandemic.

![Americans believe China's influence will decrease after the pandemic](image3)

However, these perceptions are not uniform across the American political spectrum.  Significant partisan differences exist, with Republicans holding considerably more negative views of China compared to Democrats [4].  A notable partisan divide is observed in the anticipation of China's future global influence.  Roughly six-in-ten Republicans predict a decrease in China's international clout due to the coronavirus outbreak, while only $40\%$ of Democrats share this view [5].  This partisan divergence in unfavorable views of China is a trend that has been increasing over recent years, particularly pronounced in 2020.

![Unfavorable views of China increased significantly among Republicans in 2020](image4)

Furthermore, partisan lines are evident in the assessment of China's handling of the crisis, with Republicans being considerably more critical than Democrats [7].  In summary, Americans generally view China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak negatively and anticipate a decrease in China's global influence, with pronounced partisan divisions in these perceptions, particularly with Republicans holding more critical views.

The survey reveals significant partisan divisions concerning the U.S.'s approach to global challenges.  A notable gap exists in the perception of whether the U.S. is overextended in its international involvement, with Republicans increasingly believing that the U.S. is doing "too much" to address global challenges. [5]

This partisan divergence has widened considerably since 2013, as depicted in the trend lines.  The percentage of Republicans who feel the U.S. is doing "too much" has risen, while Democrats' views have remained relatively stable or decreased. ![Line chart showing Republicans increasingly believe the U.S. does 'too much' in world affairs, diverging from Democrats' views from 2013 to 2020.](image4)

Specifically regarding the coronavirus pandemic, partisan lines are sharply drawn on whether the U.S. can learn from other nations in managing the crisis. Most Americans acknowledge the potential for learning from other countries, but this view is stronger among Democrats. [2] [1] Democrats are significantly more inclined to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations about slowing the virus's spread. ![Bar chart showing Democrats are more likely than Republicans to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal or a fair amount from other countries about slowing the spread of coronavirus.](image1)

Furthermore, partisan ideologies influence expectations about America's global standing post-pandemic.  Democrats are considerably more likely than Republicans to anticipate a weakening of U.S. influence in world affairs due to the coronavirus outbreak. [10] Liberal Democrats, in particular, express a bleak outlook on the pandemic's impact on U.S. global influence. [7]

In summary, partisan views diverge significantly on the U.S.'s role in global affairs, with Republicans increasingly favoring a reduced international role and Democrats more open to global cooperation and acknowledging potential lessons from other nations, especially in the context of the coronavirus pandemic, leading to differing expectations about the future of U.S. global influence.

Based on surveys, most Americans agree that the U.S. can learn from other countries about managing the coronavirus [3, 5]. However, partisan lines emerge when considering the extent of this learning and the broader implications for America's global role.

While a majority across the political spectrum believes the U.S. can learn at least a fair amount from other nations, Democrats are significantly more inclined to think the U.S. can learn a "great deal." For instance, 67% of liberal Democrats hold this view, compared to only 25% of conservative Republicans [4].  ![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to say the U.S. can learn a great deal from other countries about slowing coronavirus.](image1) This partisan gap is visually represented, showing that 60% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents believe the U.S. can learn a great deal, whereas only 28% of Republicans and Republican leaners share this sentiment [8].

Furthermore, partisan views diverge sharply on the assessment of the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic and its future global influence.  A large majority of liberal Democrats (81%) believe the U.S. has done only a fair or poor job managing the coronavirus outbreak, while only a small fraction of conservative Republicans (22%) agree [6].  Liberal Democrats are also considerably more pessimistic about America's global standing, with 56% believing the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic, a view significantly less common among Republicans [6]. ![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal about slowing the spread of coronavirus and that the U.S. will have less world influence after the coronavirus outbreak.](image5)

In conclusion, partisan views significantly differ regarding the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries about coronavirus and the pandemic's impact on U.S. global influence, with Democrats being more open to learning from abroad and more critical of the U.S.'s response and future global standing compared to Republicans.

Based on a survey conducted by the PEW Research Center, a majority of Americans (60%) believe that the U.S. should concentrate on its own domestic issues and allow other nations to handle their challenges independently [2].  However, there are notable differences in these views when considering political affiliations.  For example, a significant majority of Republicans (around three-quarters) prefer the U.S. to focus on its own problems [6]. This perspective is consistent across different ideological wings within the Republican party [6].  ![Republicans prefer the U.S. deal with its own problems and let other countries deal as best they can.](image1)

Conversely, Democrats are more divided on this issue. While nearly half (46%) think the U.S. should focus domestically, a larger portion (around half) believes the U.S. should assist other countries with their problems [4].  This view is particularly strong among liberal Democrats, with a substantial majority (64%) supporting international assistance compared to conservative and moderate Democrats (44%) [4]. ![Democrats are more divided, with liberal Democrats most likely to support helping other countries.](image1)

Educational attainment also plays a role in shaping these opinions.  Individuals with higher education levels are more inclined to support the U.S. in helping other countries.  Specifically, six-in-ten postgraduates believe the U.S. should offer international assistance. In contrast, those with only a high school diploma or less education largely prefer the U.S. to address its own problems [9]. ![Postgraduates are more likely to support the U.S. helping other countries, while those with less education prefer domestic focus.](image1)

In summary, views on whether the U.S. should deal with its own problems versus helping other countries are significantly influenced by both political affiliation, with Republicans favoring domestic focus and Democrats being more divided, and educational level, where higher education correlates with greater support for international assistance.

The perception of the U.S.’s role in solving global issues is significantly shaped by political affiliation, with Republicans and Democrats holding divergent views [3]. Currently, a majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. is doing too much to aid in resolving global problems, whereas a plurality of Democrats (48%) feel the U.S. is doing too little [3]. This partisan gap is further highlighted when considering whether the U.S. should prioritize its own problems versus assisting other nations.  ![Republicans are more likely to believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems, while Democrats are more inclined to think the U.S. should help other countries, with further divisions along ideological lines within each party.](image2)  A large majority of Republicans (about three-quarters) advocate for the U.S. to focus domestically, a view similarly held across conservative and moderate Republicans [8]. Conversely, Democrats are more divided, with a slim majority favoring international assistance; this inclination is stronger among liberal Democrats (64%) compared to conservative and moderate Democrats (44%) [7].

Over time, this partisan divide has become more pronounced [6].  In 2020, 42% of Americans overall think the U.S. does too much to solve world problems [9].  ![The percentage of Americans who think the U.S. does too much to solve world problems has increased since 2013, while those who think it does too little or the right amount has decreased or remained stable.](image1)  Specifically looking at Republicans, the trend of feeling the U.S. does "too much" has increased significantly from 2013 to 2020. ![The percentage of Republicans who think the U.S. does too much to solve world problems has increased sharply from 2013 to 2020.](image3) On the other hand, Democrats are increasingly feeling that the U.S. is doing "too little" to solve world problems. ![The percentage of Democrats who think the U.S. does too little to solve world problems has increased and become the majority view from 2013 to 2020.](image5)
