Workers with higher education tend to view technology more positively in their professional lives [3]. For instance, college graduates are considerably more inclined to agree that technology has made their work more interesting and has broadened their career prospects [8].  In contrast, individuals without a college degree are less likely to hold such positive views regarding workplace technologies [5]. ![College graduates are more likely to report technology has made work more interesting and increased career opportunities, compared to those with less education.](image4) This difference in perception is visually represented, highlighting the disparity in how different education groups perceive technology's influence on their work experience and career advancement.

Younger adults, specifically those aged 18 to 24, are more likely to report personal experiences of job loss or reduced pay due to employers adopting machines or computer programs [2].  This direct experience with automation's negative impacts may shape their attitudes.  ![Younger adults (18-24) are more likely to have experienced job loss due to automation compared to other age groups.](image3) The data indicates that younger demographics are experiencing the immediate effects of workforce automation more acutely than older age groups.

In conclusion, attitudes towards workforce automation and technology's impact are shaped by both education level and age, with higher education correlating with more positive views and younger age groups reporting more direct negative impacts.

The perception of technology's impact in the workforce is varied, with educational attainment playing a significant role in shaping these views [8].  Workers express mixed opinions on how technologies have affected their jobs and careers [3].  However, a significant disparity exists based on education levels, as those without a college education are notably less likely to hold positive views about current workforce technologies [2].

For instance, college graduates are considerably more inclined to believe that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their career opportunities compared to those with only a high school diploma or less [1]. Specifically, 64% of college graduates find their work more interesting due to technology, versus only 38% of those with less education [1].  Similarly, 53% of college graduates believe technology has boosted their career advancement prospects, compared to just 32% of their less-educated counterparts [1].  This educational divide in perception is visually represented, highlighting the difference in how technology is viewed based on educational background. ![College graduates are more likely than those with less education to perceive technology as making work more interesting and increasing career opportunities.](image4)

Moreover, when examining specific technologies, this trend persists. College-educated workers are significantly more likely to report a positive impact from technologies such as word processing software, smartphones, email, and even industrial robots [7]. This indicates that the benefits of these technological tools are more readily recognized and appreciated by individuals with higher levels of formal education [4, 6]. In contrast, workers with lower educational attainment are less inclined to see technology as a positive force in their professional lives [6, 9].

While education is a key differentiator, age also plays a role in related concerns about automation. Younger adults are more likely to be concerned about job displacement due to automation. ![Younger adults are more likely to express concern about job displacement due to automation compared to older age groups.](image1)

In conclusion, perceptions of workforce automation and technology's impact are not uniform across demographics; they are significantly shaped by education levels, with college graduates generally viewing technology more positively than those with less education, and age influencing related concerns about job displacement.

Workers' perceptions of job interest and advancement opportunities are shaped by both their level of education and the specific technologies they encounter in their work.  Overall, workers express mixed views regarding the impact of technology on their careers [4]. However, a general positive sentiment prevails, with more workers feeling that technology has made their work more interesting rather than less so [2].  Specifically, 53% of workers find their work more interesting due to technology.

![Most workers find technology makes their work more interesting, with 53% reporting increased interest compared to 12% who find it less interesting.](image1)

This positive view extends to career advancement, where a plurality of workers, 46%, believe technology has increased their career opportunities [2].

![More workers believe technology increases career opportunities, with 46% reporting increased opportunities compared to 13% who report decreased opportunities.](image3)

However, these benefits are not uniformly distributed across all education levels. Workers with higher education are significantly more likely to perceive technology as a positive influence, enhancing both job interest and career prospects [3].  Those with college degrees are considerably more inclined to agree that technology has boosted their career opportunities and made their jobs more engaging [6].  For instance, a substantial gap exists between college-educated workers and those with only a high school diploma or less in terms of perceiving technology's positive impact on job interest and career advancement [7].  As illustrated, 64% of college graduates believe technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [7].

![Workers with higher education levels are more likely to agree that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their career advancement opportunities.](image2)

Furthermore, the perception of specific technologies varies.  Technologies like word processing and spreadsheet software, smartphones, and email and social media are widely seen as having a positive impact on careers [9].  For example, 70% of workers believe word processing and spreadsheet software have positively impacted their careers [9].

![Most workers view technologies like word processing, smartphones, and email as having a positive impact on their careers, while industrial robots are seen as having a less positive impact.](image4)

In conclusion, workers' perception of job interest and advancement is positively influenced by technology, especially for those with higher education levels, and this perception is further shaped by the specific types of technologies encountered in their work.

Social media platforms evoke a spectrum of emotions in their users, with variations observed across different age groups. Younger adults are more inclined to encounter content that brings amusement compared to older adults [1]. In fact, 54% of younger adults report frequently seeing amusing content, double the percentage who frequently encounter anger-inducing content [1].

![Younger adults are more amused than older adults, while older adults experience amusement and anger at comparable rates on social media.](image2)

Conversely, older users, aged 65 and above, experience amusement and anger at more similar frequencies, with 30% feeling amused and 24% feeling angry from social media content [1, 5].  Notably, younger adults are also more susceptible to feelings of loneliness on social media, with 15% of 18- to 29-year-olds reporting frequent loneliness compared to only 4% of those 50 and older [5, 9].

Despite these age-related differences, amusement stands out as the most commonly experienced emotion across all social media users [7].  A large majority, 88% of users, encounter content that amuses them, and 44% frequently feel amused [7].

![Amusement is the most frequently experienced emotion by social media users.](image3)

While amusement is predominant, negative emotions like anger are also significant, with 25% of users frequently encountering anger-inducing content [6].  Overall, social media frequently exposes users to content that sparks amusement, but also material that angers them [3].

In conclusion, while amusement is the most frequently experienced emotion on social media for all users, younger adults are more prone to amusement and loneliness, whereas older adults experience amusement and anger at comparable rates.

Social media platforms evoke anger across different age demographics, yet the spectrum of emotions experienced shows variation depending on age [1].  ![Image1 shows the percentage of social media users in different age groups who frequently experience emotions such as amusement, anger, loneliness, etc.](image1)  Notably, younger adults, specifically those aged 18 to 29, are more inclined to report frequent feelings of loneliness from social media content compared to older age groups [1]. Conversely, older adults report experiencing amusement from social media content less often than younger demographics [1].  Moreover, social media users are frequently exposed to content characterized by exaggerated drama and arguments lacking complete information [5]. ![Image4 shows the percentage of users who frequently see overly dramatic posts and argumentative content](image4) Different age groups on social media experience a diverse range of emotions with varying frequencies, and they are commonly exposed to content that is often dramatic or argumentative.

Social media users' emotional experiences and perceptions of online behavior vary across age groups. Younger adults (18-29) are notably more inclined to report feelings of loneliness and amusement from social media content compared to older adults [7].  For example, 15% of users aged 18-29 feel lonely frequently, whereas only 4% of those 50 and older share this sentiment [7]. Conversely, older adults are less frequently amused by social media content, with similar percentages feeling amused (30%) and angry (24%) [7].

![Younger adults are more likely to feel lonely and amused on social media, while older adults are less frequently amused but experience similar levels of amusement and anger.](image2)

Regarding gender differences in online behavior perception, men are slightly more likely than women to encounter mean or bullying content [2]. Specifically, 29% of men reported frequently seeing mean or bullying content, compared to 19% of women [2].  Furthermore, men are about twice as likely as women to perceive deceptive behavior on social media more often [10].

![Men are more likely to perceive mean, bullying, and deceptive behavior on social media, while women are more inclined to see kind and supportive behavior.](image4)

Across all demographics, social media users frequently encounter certain types of content.  A large majority, 58% and 59% respectively, frequently see posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated and people making accusations or starting arguments without complete information [4].  These types of content are significantly more common than posts that teach something new or are subtly misleading [5].

![Overly dramatic/exaggerated posts and people arguing without facts are the most frequently encountered content types on social media.](image5)

In conclusion, emotional responses and behavior perceptions on social media are influenced by age and gender, with younger users experiencing more loneliness and amusement, men perceiving more negative behaviors, and dramatic or argumentative content being frequently encountered by most users.

Social media users' experiences vary across age groups and genders in terms of emotions and encountered behaviors.  Many users frequently encounter content that evokes amusement and anger.  According to the survey, a large percentage of users, 88% and 71% respectively, report feeling amused and angry either frequently or sometimes when using social media. ![Users frequently or sometimes feel amused and angry on social media](image2)

Breaking down by age groups, younger users (18-29) are more likely to frequently feel amused (54%) compared to older users (65+), who are less likely to feel amused (30%).  For anger, the frequency is relatively consistent across age groups, ranging from 23% to 27%. ![Frequency of emotions felt by different age groups on social media](image4)

In terms of behaviors, users are exposed to both positive and negative interactions.  A large portion of social media users, 54%, perceive an equal mix of kindness and bullying. However, men are slightly more inclined (29%) than women (19%) to report seeing more mean or bullying content. ![Gender differences in perceived online behavior on social media](image3)

Furthermore, users frequently encounter specific types of posts.  Overly dramatic or exaggerated posts and posts involving accusations or arguments without complete information are commonly seen by users, with 58% and 59% respectively reporting frequent exposure. [9] ![Frequency of encountering different types of posts on social media](image5)

Social media users' emotional and behavioral experiences are diverse, with age and gender influencing perceptions of content and interactions, while dramatic and argumentative posts are frequently encountered by a majority.

From the survey, men and women show notable differences in their perceptions of negative online behaviors. Men are more inclined than women to perceive others as bullying or deceptive on social media [9]. Specifically, 29% of men report seeing more bullying behavior compared to 19% of women, and 24% of men more often see deceptive behavior versus 13% of women [10].

![Men are more likely than women to perceive bullying and deception on social media, while women are more likely to perceive kindness.](image1)

Despite these differences, majorities of both men and women agree that they frequently encounter dramatic or exaggerated content on social media [7].  A significant 58% of social media users report frequently seeing overly dramatic or exaggerated posts [3].

![Dramatic and argumentative posts are frequently seen by social media users.](image4)

While men are more likely to perceive deception and bullying, and both genders frequently encounter dramatic content, the survey indicates that most users, regardless of gender, tend to see a mix of positive and negative behaviors online, with a large portion witnessing an equal balance of kindness and bullying, as well as deception and attempts to correct misinformation [8, 5].

In conclusion, men are more likely to perceive bullying and deception online compared to women, although both genders frequently encounter dramatic and exaggerated content and generally perceive a mix of positive and negative behaviors on social media.

Based on survey results, men and women have different perceptions of online behavior on social media platforms. Men are more inclined to perceive negativity, while women lean towards positivity or balance in online interactions [4]. For example, a larger percentage of men (29%) report frequently seeing mean or bullying content compared to women (19%) [4]. This is further supported by the observation that men are somewhat more likely to witness bullying and deceptive behavior on social media [8].  Men are also about twice as likely as women to report seeing people being deceptive on social media (24% vs. 13%) [10].

![Men are more likely than women to perceive bullying and deception on social media, while women are more likely to perceive kindness or support.](image2)

Despite these differences in perception of negative behaviors, both men and women largely agree that they see an equal mix of supportive and bullying behaviors, as indicated by 52% of men and 56% of women reporting this [4].  However, when it comes to deception and misinformation, a greater percentage of women (67%) than men (58%) perceive an equal mix of deceptive attempts and efforts to correct misinformation [10].  This suggests that while men might be more sensitive to outright negative behaviors like bullying and deception, women may have a more nuanced view of the information landscape, perceiving a balance between misinformation and correction attempts.

These differing perceptions could influence how social media platforms tailor content. If men are more likely to perceive negative behaviors such as bullying and deception, platforms might consider algorithms that prioritize content moderation and positivity for male users, or at least be mindful of the potentially higher sensitivity of male users to negative content. Conversely, while women also see negative content, their slightly higher inclination to perceive kindness and support, and their nuanced view of misinformation correction, might suggest a different content preference or at least a different tolerance level for certain types of content.  Social media platforms utilize user data to deliver targeted content [2], and understanding these gender-based perception differences can refine how platforms tailor recommendations and advertisements to better resonate with different user demographics.

In conclusion, men and women exhibit notable differences in their perceptions of social media content and behavior, particularly regarding negativity and deception, which has implications for how social media platforms can tailor content to user preferences based on gender.

Social media users' comfort levels with platforms using their personal data are heavily influenced by the context of data usage [7, 8].  A significant majority, $75\%$, are comfortable if their data recommends events, but this drops to $37\%$ for political messages [1]. This context-dependent comfort is further highlighted by differing views across age groups [6, 9].  For instance, recommending events is broadly acceptable across ages [3, 9], as shown in the image.

![Acceptability of recommending events is high across age groups.](image1)

However, differences emerge when considering other uses of data.  While a large majority of users aged 18-49 find it acceptable for platforms to use their data to suggest people they might know, this view is not shared by older users [10].  Specifically, two-thirds of users under 50 find it acceptable for recommendations of people, but less than half of users 65 and older agree [6].  This divergence is visually represented, showing a clear drop in acceptability among older users for recommending connections.

![Acceptability of recommending connections decreases with age.](image1)

Furthermore, even for product and service advertisements, where overall acceptability is around half of users [5], older users are less accepting [10].  In contrast, political campaign messages are largely unacceptable across all age groups [3, 5], with a substantial majority finding it unacceptable, and $31\%$ finding it 'not acceptable at all' [5].  This is reflected in the low acceptability percentages across age groups for political messages in the image.

![Acceptability of political messages is low across age groups.](image1)

Overall user comfort with social media data practices is highly dependent on the specific purpose for which the data is used, and age plays a significant role in shaping these perceptions, particularly for uses beyond event recommendations.

The public's perceptions of fairness and effectiveness in automated systems vary significantly depending on the system's application. Generally, people tend to view systems as both fair and effective, or neither. However, personal finance scores stand out as a notable exception to this trend [4].  While a similar proportion of people believe in the effectiveness of both personal finance scores (54%) and criminal risk scores (49%) [1], there's a stark contrast in perceived fairness.

![54% think personal finance score algorithm is effective while 49% think criminal risk score is effective.](image3)

Americans are more inclined to consider criminal risk scores fair (50%) compared to personal finance scores (only 32%) [1]. This disparity is highlighted in Image 3, which shows a significant +22 percentage point difference between perceived effectiveness and fairness for automated personal finance scores, the largest gap among the scenarios presented.

![Only 32% think personal finance score is fair while 50% think criminal risk score is fair.](image4)

The skepticism surrounding personal finance scores is further underscored by the fact that only a small fraction of Americans deem them fair (32%) [7]. This is reflected in Image 4, which shows a substantial portion of respondents finding personal finance scores "not fair at all" or "not very fair."  Moreover, a large majority (68%) find the use of personal finance score algorithms generally unacceptable [9].

![68% Americans find personal finance score algorithm unacceptable.](image2)

Reasons for this unacceptability, as shown in Image 2, include concerns about privacy violations, inaccurate personal representation, and unfair or discriminatory practices.  This contrasts with criminal risk scores, which, despite having similar effectiveness ratings, are viewed more favorably in terms of fairness [1].  This context-dependent perception suggests that public trust in automated systems is not solely determined by their perceived effectiveness, but is heavily influenced by ethical considerations and the perceived fairness of their application.  Many Americans harbor a general skepticism about algorithms, with 58% believing that computer programs inevitably reflect human bias [6].

![58% of Americans believe computer programs reflect human bias.](image1)

This underlying concern about bias, coupled with specific reservations about fairness in certain applications like personal finance, erodes public trust in algorithmic decision-making, particularly when these systems are perceived as judging individuals unfairly [9, 10].

In conclusion, perceptions of fairness and effectiveness in automated systems diverge significantly across different applications, with personal finance scores facing substantial skepticism regarding fairness despite perceived effectiveness, implying that public trust in these systems is contingent on both efficacy and strong ethical considerations, especially fairness and lack of bias.

Public perception indicates that ethical standards of top Trump administration officials are at historic lows compared to previous administrations [1].  A significant majority of the public, 58%, express less trust in what President Trump says compared to previous presidents, while only 26% trust him more [9].

![Views of ethical standards as excellent or good are the lowest for Trump compared to previous presidents like Reagan, G.H.W. Bush, Clinton, G.W. Bush, and Obama.](image1)

This distrust is particularly pronounced among Democrats and those leaning Democratic, with 94% trusting Trump less than previous presidents [2].  Conversely, a majority of Republicans and Republican leaners, 58%, report trusting Trump more than previous presidents [6]. This partisan divide is further highlighted in views on ethical standards, where 90% of Democrats rate Trump administration ethical standards as "not good or poor," while 76% of Republicans rate them as "excellent or good" [10].

![A majority of Democrats perceive ethical standards in the Trump administration as "not too/not at all good," whereas a majority of Republicans view them as "very/somewhat good."](image2)

![Most Democrats trust Trump's rhetoric "less than" previous presidents, while most Republicans trust him "more than" previous presidents.](image4)

These differing perceptions along party lines demonstrate a deep partisan divide in how Trump's ethical conduct and trustworthiness are viewed compared to his predecessors.  Overall, public trust and ethical ratings for the Trump administration are notably lower than those for previous administrations, especially when considering views outside of the Republican party [4, 7].

Public perception indicates a notable difference in how Trump's responsibilities and trustworthiness are viewed compared to previous presidents, especially when considering partisan divides.  A majority of the public believes Trump had a responsibility to release his tax returns [3].  This view has been consistently held by a majority, with 64% agreeing he should release them [3].  Notably, there is a significant partisan split on this issue, with nearly all Democrats (91%) and a smaller percentage of Republicans (32%) believing Trump should release his tax returns [3].

![The graph shows that in January 2019, 64% of total respondents, 32% of Republican/Lean Republican respondents, and 91% of Democrat/Lean Democrat respondents believe Trump has a responsibility to release tax returns.](image1)

Furthermore, a majority of the public expresses less trust in what Trump says compared to previous presidents [9].  Specifically, 58% of the public trust Trump less than previous presidents, while only 26% trust him more [10].  This distrust has increased since earlier in his presidency [7].  However, this perception varies significantly along partisan lines.

![The chart illustrates that 58% of total respondents trust Trump less than previous presidents, while 58% of Republican/Lean Republican respondents trust Trump more, and 94% of Democrat/Lean Democrat respondents trust Trump less than previous presidents.](image3)

While a large portion of Republicans trust Trump more than previous presidents (58%), an overwhelming majority of Democrats (94%) trust him less [8].  This partisan divergence highlights the deeply polarized views on Trump's trustworthiness [5].  Adding to this, the ethical standards of top officials in the Trump administration are perceived to be lower than in previous administrations [4].  These lower ethical views are record lows compared to administrations dating back to the 1980s [2].

![The bar chart compares the percentage of public who believe it is too early to tell if president will be successful for Clinton, Bush, Obama and Trump at comparable points in their presidencies, showing that for Trump in Jan 2019, it's 23%.](image2)

Interestingly, the public was quicker to form an opinion on Trump's potential success compared to previous presidents.  Fewer people believed it was "too early to tell" if Trump would be successful at a comparable point in his presidency compared to Obama, Bush, and Clinton [6].

In conclusion, public perception reveals that a majority holds Trump to the responsibility of releasing his tax returns and generally trusts his statements less than those of previous presidents, with these views being heavily influenced and divided along partisan lines.

Perceptions of Donald Trump's presidency are notably polarized along political lines, especially when it comes to ethical standards. Views on the ethical conduct of top Trump administration officials are at historically low levels compared to previous administrations, indicating a significant decline in public trust [1].  This is further emphasized by the fact that views of Trump administration officials are generally lower than those of officials in the past five administrations, even when considering times of specific ethical controversies [7].

![Democrats view ethical standards of Trump administration officials much lower than Republicans.](image2)

Partisan divisions are stark: a large majority of Republicans believe the ethical standards are good or excellent, while an overwhelming majority of Democrats consider them not good or poor [10].  Despite the overall negative perception of ethical standards, public opinion is somewhat more positive regarding Trump's impact on the economy.  A notable portion of the public believes that Trump's policies have improved economic conditions since he took office [4].

![Public views on Trump's economic policies improving conditions in Jan 2019 compared to Oct 2017.](image4)

Interestingly, partisan views on Trump's economic policies have intensified, with Republicans becoming more positive and Democrats more negative since 2017 [9].  When considering long-term success, public expectations for Trump's presidency are relatively low.  About half of the public anticipates Trump will be unsuccessful in the long run, which is more negative than ratings for Obama and George W. Bush at similar points in their presidencies [5].

![Comparison of public expectation of presidential success in the long run for Trump, Obama, Bush, and Clinton at comparable points in their administrations.](image3)

However, Republicans hold a much more optimistic view, with a majority believing Trump will be successful long-term, mirroring Republican views of George W. Bush during his third year [3, 6].  Furthermore, fewer people feel it's "too early to tell" about Trump's success compared to previous presidents at similar stages in their terms, suggesting a more decisive public opinion, whether positive or negative [2, 5].  Partisan divides on long-term success are also evident, with strong Republican support and strong Democratic skepticism [5].

![Partisan views on presidential long-term success for Trump, Obama, Bush, and Clinton.](image5)

In conclusion, perceptions of Trump's presidency reveal deep partisan divides across ethical standards, economic impact, and long-term success, with overall lower public trust and expectations compared to previous administrations, although Republicans maintain a positive outlook, particularly on economic matters and long-term success.

Public perceptions of Donald Trump's presidency are notably polarized along party lines and show distinct trends when compared to those of Barack Obama, George W. Bush, and Bill Clinton. Republicans are significantly more inclined to view Trump as successful, while Democrats largely anticipate his failure.

For instance, approximately two-thirds of Republicans believed Trump would be a successful president in the long term [1]. In stark contrast, a large majority of Democrats held the opposite view, expecting an unsuccessful presidency [5]. This partisan divergence is visually represented in the chart, showing that 65% of Republicans/Lean Republicans anticipated Trump's success, while only 3% of Democrats/Lean Democrats shared this view in January 2019.  ![In January 2019, 65% of Republican/Lean Republican anticipated Trump to be successful president, compared to only 3% of Democrats/Lean Democrats.](image1)

Compared to previous presidents, there is a stronger tendency to have a definitive view on Trump's success rather than reserving judgment.  A smaller percentage of the public felt it was "too early to tell" regarding Trump's presidency compared to Obama, Bush, and Clinton at comparable points in their terms [4].  As shown in the graph, the "too early to tell" sentiment for Trump in January 2019 was lower than for Obama in January 2011, Bush in December 2003, and Clinton in February 1995. ![The percentage of people who said it was too early to tell for Trump in Jan 2019 is lower than Obama in Jan 2011, Bush in Dec 2003, and Clinton in Feb 1995.](image3) This suggests a more immediate and decisive public opinion on Trump's potential legacy.

Furthermore, negative assessments of Trump's long-term success are more pronounced than those faced by his recent predecessors.  Nearly half of Americans anticipated Trump's unsuccessful presidency, a higher proportion than was predicted for Obama, Bush, or Clinton at similar junctures in their first terms [9, 6].  This indicates a more negative overall outlook on Trump's presidency compared to the initial perceptions of Obama, Bush, and Clinton.

Partisan polarization also extends to perceptions of Trump's economic policies, which have intensified over time.  Republicans have become increasingly positive about Trump's economic impact, with nearly eight in ten believing his policies improved the economy in January 2019, a rise from 63% in October 2017 [8, 7]. Conversely, Democrats have grown more critical, demonstrating a widening partisan gap in economic policy evaluations. ![In Jan 2019, 79% of Republicans/Lean Republicans believed Trump's economic policies improved the condition, increased from 63% in Oct 2017.](image2)

In conclusion, perceptions of Trump's presidency are characterized by strong partisan divides, a greater certainty in public opinion (less "too early to tell"), and a more pronounced negative outlook compared to the early years of Obama, Bush, and Clinton's presidencies.

Republicans are more inclined to believe in Trump's future success, with a significant portion thinking he will be successful in the long run [6], and some suggesting it's still too early to judge [1]. ![Republican respondents believe Trump will be successful.](image3)

However, Democrats hold a contrasting view, with a large majority anticipating an unsuccessful presidency for Trump [3]. ![Democratic respondents believe Trump will be unsuccessful.](image3)

This partisan divide extends to the Mueller investigation, where Democrats express confidence in its fairness [7], ![Democrats are somewhat or very confident in Mueller's investigation.](image2) while Republicans tend to be less confident [7]. ![Republicans are not too or not at all confident in Mueller's investigation.](image2)

Notably, Democrats also overwhelmingly lack confidence in Trump's handling of matters related to the Mueller investigation [9].

In conclusion, Republican respondents are more optimistic about Trump's success and less confident in the Mueller investigation, while Democratic respondents hold opposite views.

Perceptions of job availability have generally become more positive across the population [3, 9].  Six-in-ten adults currently perceive that there are plenty of jobs available in their local communities, marking the highest point since 2001 [3]. This positive trend is also reflected in the increasing percentage of people believing there are "plenty of jobs available" as depicted in the line chart.

![Line chart shows that the percentage of people who believe "Plenty of jobs available" has increased from 2001 to 2019, while the percentage of people who believe "Jobs are difficult to find" has decreased in the same period.](image1)

However, a significant partisan divide exists in these perceptions [2, 7].  Republicans consistently express more optimistic views on job availability compared to Democrats [2, 6, 7]. Currently, 71% of Republicans believe there are plenty of jobs available, whereas 53% of Democrats share this view [2]. This partisan gap is also evident when examining views on personal financial situations, where Republicans are more likely to rate their situation as excellent or good [7].  The bar chart further illustrates this divide, showing that Republicans are more likely to say there are plenty of jobs available compared to Democrats.

![Bar chart shows that 71% of Republicans say "Plenty of jobs available" compared to 53% of Democrats, and 23% of Republicans say "Jobs are difficult to find" compared to 39% of Democrats.](image3)

Looking at trends over time, perceptions of job availability have improved for both Republicans and Democrats [1, 5].  Notably, views of job opportunities in both parties are among the most positive they have been in the last two decades [5].  However, the partisan gap persists and fluctuates over different periods. The line graph showing trends by party affiliation demonstrates that Republicans' and Democrats' perceptions of economic conditions diverge and converge, often aligning with the political party in power.  For instance, the gap widened notably post-2016, coinciding with the Trump administration.

![Line chart shows that Republicans’ views on economic conditions are consistently higher than Democrats’, and the gap between them widens after 2016.](image5)

In conclusion, while overall perceptions of job availability are at their most positive in decades, a significant partisan gap persists with Republicans holding more optimistic views than Democrats, and these perceptions are influenced by political dynamics over time.

Perceptions of job availability are significantly divided along partisan lines, with Republicans expressing more positive views than Democrats [2, 10]. Currently, majorities in both parties perceive plenty of jobs available locally, with a notable gap: 71% of Republicans compared to 53% of Democrats [2].  This partisan divide in job availability perception is visually represented in the provided line chart, showcasing trends from 2001 to 2019. ![Line chart displaying partisan perceptions of job availability over time, showing a consistent gap between Republicans and Democrats](image1).  The chart shows that Republicans (red line) consistently report higher percentages believing jobs are plentiful compared to Democrats (blue line).

Furthermore, public perception of local job availability has reached its most positive point in decades for both parties [3, 6, 7].  As indicated in the text, positive views on job availability have increased since October 2017, mirroring a broader trend of more positive economic views [4].  The line chart reinforces this trend, illustrating an upward trajectory in job availability perception for both Republicans and Democrats, especially in the period leading up to 2019. ![Line chart illustrating the upward trend in positive job availability perceptions for both Republicans and Democrats over time](image1).

In conclusion, perceptions of job availability are strongly influenced by political affiliation, with Republicans consistently holding more optimistic views than Democrats, however, overall positive perceptions of job availability have significantly increased for both groups over the past two decades.

Public opinions on Wall Street's impact on the economy are significantly divided along partisan lines, mirroring the trends observed in national satisfaction levels.  Republicans are more inclined to view Wall Street positively, with $55\%$ believing it helps the economy more than it hurts [1]. This contrasts with Democrats, who are more divided, with $46\%$ saying Wall Street hurts the economy and $41\%$ saying it helps [7]. Overall, nearly half of Americans think Wall Street helps the economy [6].

![Republicans are more likely than Democrats to believe Wall Street helps the economy.](image3)

This partisan split is further emphasized when examining satisfaction with the state of the nation.  While public dissatisfaction is generally high [5], reaching $70\%$ [3], the partisan breakdown reveals stark differences.  As seen in the graph, satisfaction levels among Republicans and Democrats diverge significantly, particularly during the Trump presidency.

![Trends in satisfaction with the state of the nation among Republicans and Democrats from 2001 to 2019 show increasing partisan divergence.](image5)

For instance, during Trump's presidency, satisfaction among Democrats has been extremely low, with no more than $16\%$ expressing satisfaction at any point [10], and currently only $8\%$ are satisfied [2]. Conversely, while Republican satisfaction has decreased from September, it remains considerably higher than that of Democrats [9]. This partisan polarization in national satisfaction aligns with the polarized views on Wall Street's impact, suggesting that political affiliation strongly influences opinions on both economic and national well-being.

In conclusion, public opinion on Wall Street's economic impact is strongly divided along partisan lines, with Republicans viewing it more favorably than Democrats, a pattern that mirrors the partisan divergence seen in national satisfaction levels.

Public satisfaction in the United States has seen a notable shift from 1990 to 2019, marked by a general decrease in satisfaction and significant partisan divisions.  Currently, a large majority of Americans express dissatisfaction with the direction of the country [1], with dissatisfaction levels reaching a peak in the past year [10].  This overall trend of declining satisfaction can be visualized in the historical data from 1990 to 2019.

![The graph illustrates the trend of public satisfaction and dissatisfaction from 1990 to 2019, indicating a recent increase in dissatisfaction and decrease in satisfaction.](image2)

Examining this trend through a partisan lens reveals a stark contrast between Democrats and Republicans.  As of recent surveys, only a small fraction of Democrats are satisfied with the nation's state, while a vast majority are dissatisfied [6].  Conversely, Republicans, who were previously more satisfied, now show a near balance between satisfaction and dissatisfaction, with a recent decline in their satisfaction levels [5].  This partisan divergence in satisfaction has become particularly pronounced in recent years, as visualized in the trend from 1990 to 2019.

![The graph illustrates the satisfaction trend by party affiliation from 1990 to 2019, showing a stark partisan divide, especially during the Trump presidency.](image5)

This partisan polarization in public satisfaction extends to views on economic matters, such as the impact of Wall Street.  Republicans are more inclined to perceive Wall Street as beneficial to the economy, while Democrats are more divided in their assessment, with a significant portion believing Wall Street is detrimental [3, 7].  Overall, Americans are slightly more inclined to believe that Wall Street helps rather than hurts the economy [8].

![The bar chart shows the views on Wall Street's impact on the economy, broken down by party affiliation, revealing a partisan divide in perception.](image4)

In conclusion, public satisfaction has broadly decreased from 1990 to 2019, accompanied by a deepening partisan divide in satisfaction and views on Wall Street's economic impact, reflecting a broader trend of political polarization in the US.

Public confidence in Trump's ability to appoint federal judges differs significantly between Republicans and Democrats, mirroring the partisan divide seen in other areas like trade negotiations [1].  Republicans overwhelmingly express confidence in Trump's ability to negotiate favorable trade agreements [1].

![Republicans are very confident, while Democrats are not confident at all, regarding Trump's ability to negotiate trade agreements and appoint federal judges](image3)

Conversely, Democrats show very little confidence in Trump across various domains, including trade and federal appointments [1, 4].  Overall public confidence in Trump's ability to make good decisions on economic policy and trade is moderate, with about half expressing confidence [3, 10].

![Public confidence in Trump's ability to appoint federal judges and handle economic policy is moderate, with less than half expressing confidence in both](image1)

However, confidence in his ability to work with Congress is notably lower compared to these areas [8, 10].  There is a clear partisan split in confidence regarding Trump's abilities, with Republicans being far more confident than Democrats, particularly in areas like trade agreements and federal appointments.

The public expresses considerable doubt regarding President Trump's capacity to distinguish his business engagements from his presidential responsibilities [4].  ![A majority of Americans are not too or not at all confident that Trump separates his business and presidential decisions, with significant partisan divisions.](image3)  This lack of confidence is particularly pronounced among Democrats, where nearly seven in ten express no confidence at all in this separation [2]. Liberal Democrats are even more skeptical, with over eighty percent doubting Trump's ability to keep these spheres separate [2].

Conversely, Republicans generally maintain confidence that Trump can separate his business interests from his presidential actions [10].  ![Republicans are largely confident Trump separates business and presidential roles, contrasting sharply with Democrats' views.](image4)  A majority of Republicans are either very or somewhat confident in this regard, with conservative Republicans expressing even stronger confidence compared to moderate and liberal Republicans [10].

Despite these differing confidence levels, a majority of Americans believe Trump should release his tax returns [8]. However, most Republicans do not think releasing his tax returns is a responsibility he holds [3].

Overall, public confidence in Trump's ability to separate his business interests from his presidential decisions is low, particularly among Democrats, and contrasts with the view held by most Republicans; this issue is distinct from the widespread public view that Trump should release his tax returns, a responsibility which Republicans are less likely to ascribe to him.

Partisan divides significantly shape perceptions of the COVID-19 response effectiveness and trust in institutions.  A notable example is the vastly different views on the effectiveness of the U.S. response to the coronavirus compared to other wealthy nations.  While a small percentage of Republicans believe the U.S. response was more effective, the majority find it less or about as effective, contrasting sharply with Democrats, where an overwhelming majority see the U.S. response as less effective [1].

![Republicans are more likely than Democrats to say the U.S. coronavirus response is more effective compared to other wealthy countries, but most across parties believe it is less or about as effective.](image1)

This partisan divergence extends to the assessment of public health officials.  Republicans' positive ratings for public health officials like those at the CDC have decreased significantly, while Democrats' positive views have remained largely consistent [4]. This shift indicates a growing partisan gap in trust towards institutions like the CDC.

![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to rate public health officials and other officials' COVID-19 response positively, while views on hospitals' response are similar across parties.](image2)

Overall, partisan affiliation is a stronger predictor of opinions on the COVID-19 pandemic and response strategies than geographic location or the actual impact of the virus in different areas [6].  This demonstrates that political identity plays a central role in how individuals perceive and evaluate the crisis and the authorities managing it [10].

In conclusion, partisan divides profoundly influence perceptions of COVID-19 response effectiveness and trust in institutions, leading to starkly different viewpoints across the political spectrum.

Partisan differences significantly influence the perception of the COVID-19 response, particularly concerning public health officials and Donald Trump.  Initially, Republicans held positive views of public health officials, but this sentiment dramatically decreased over time [2, 10].  As stated in text quote [3], "virtually all of the decline in positive assessments coming among Republicans." This is visually represented in the first graph of image3, illustrating the steep decline in positive ratings for public health officials among Republicans from March to August, contrasting with the relatively stable positive views among Democrats.

![The graph shows public health officials' ratings by party, with Republican ratings decreasing from March to August while Democrat ratings remain stable.](image3)

Conversely, Democrats consistently held a less favorable view of Donald Trump's response, which further deteriorated [9].  "The share of Democrats who rate Trump’s response as 'poor' has risen steeply since then" [9].  Image5 highlights the stark partisan divide in August, where only a small fraction of Democrats approve of Trump's COVID-19 response, contrasting sharply with Republicans' views.

![The bar chart compares ratings of different entities' COVID-19 response by party, showing a large partisan gap in Donald Trump's rating.](image5)

While views on hospitals' responses remained consistent across party lines [4, 6], perceptions of public health officials and Donald Trump became increasingly polarized along partisan lines as the pandemic progressed from March to August, with Republican views declining and Democratic views becoming more critical. In conclusion, partisan affiliation is a major factor shaping public opinion on the COVID-19 responses of both public health officials and Donald Trump.

Public approval of public health officials has decreased significantly from March to August, dropping from 79% to 63% [1].  This decline is largely attributed to a decrease in positive views among Republicans [4]. ![The graph shows that the approval ratings for public health officials, especially among Republicans, have decreased from March to August.](image4)

Specifically, Republican approval of public health officials plummeted by 31 points, from 84% in March to 53% currently [5, 9]. ![Republicans' approval of public health officials sharply declined while Democrats' remained stable.](image4) In contrast, Democrats' positive assessments of public health officials have remained relatively stable, with 72% approving currently compared to 74% in March [5, 9].

Similarly, Donald Trump's approval rating has also decreased since March [6, 10].  His overall approval rating has fallen from 45% in March to 38% currently [10]. ![Donald Trump's approval ratings show a slight decrease from March to August.](image2)  This decrease is reflected in the rise of disapproval among Democrats, with the percentage of Democrats rating his response as "poor" increasing from 56% in March to 82% currently [8].

Partisan divisions are evident in the current approval ratings for both public health officials and Donald Trump [2, 7].  While 72% of Democrats approve of public health officials' response, only 53% of Republicans share this view [7]. ![Democrats are more likely to approve of public health officials than Republicans.](image3)  Regarding Donald Trump's performance, a significant partisan gap exists, with 77% of Republicans approving of his job performance compared to only 5% of Democrats [2]. ![Republicans are far more likely to approve of Donald Trump's job performance than Democrats.](image1)

In summary, approval ratings for both public health officials and Donald Trump have declined from March to August, with a stark partisan divergence in these changes, particularly with Republican approval decreasing more significantly than Democrats.

Americans hold broadly negative views on the overall US response to the coronavirus outbreak, with increasing criticism directed towards both Donald Trump and state government officials [3]. However, the level of criticism and perceived effectiveness differs between the two.

Evaluations of state government responses have become more negative since March [10].  ![56% of Americans rate state elected officials' COVID response as excellent or good](image1).  While positive ratings for state officials have declined, a significant percentage still view their response favorably.

In contrast, criticism of Donald Trump's handling of the pandemic is more pronounced and has increased substantially [3, 4].  ![Only 37% of Americans rate Donald Trump's COVID response as excellent or good](image1).  Nearly half of Americans now rate Trump's response as "poor," a significant rise from earlier in the pandemic [4].

In conclusion, while both state governments and Donald Trump face increasing criticism for their COVID-19 responses,  Trump's handling is perceived more negatively and faces greater criticism compared to state governments.

Americans hold broadly negative views on the overall U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak, with increasing criticism directed towards various officials, though hospitals maintain high approval ratings [1].  Evaluations of public health officials have seen a significant decline, with positive views dropping from 79% in March to 63% [2].

![Public health officials receive lower ratings than hospitals and medical centers in handling the coronavirus outbreak.](image4)

This decline is especially pronounced among Republicans, where positive ratings for public health officials fell by 31 points since March [3].  Similarly, positive evaluations for state and local government officials have decreased since March, though they still maintain majority approval [5].  In contrast, local hospitals and medical centers continue to receive overwhelmingly positive ratings, unchanged over the past few months [5].  Notably, Donald Trump faces majority criticism for his handling of COVID-19, with nearly half of Americans rating his job as ‘poor’ [6].

![Americans believe that not enough people are following social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines as a major reason for the continued coronavirus outbreak.](image1)

A significant majority of Americans believe that a key factor in the continued coronavirus outbreak is the lack of adherence to social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines [8].  As shown in the image, 75% consider this a major reason [image1].  Furthermore, a majority also believe that lifting restrictions too quickly in some places is a major contributing factor to the ongoing outbreak [8].  While there's concern about states lifting restrictions too rapidly, most Americans point to individual behavior as a primary driver for the outbreak's continuation [8].

In conclusion, Americans perceive the effectiveness of hospitals and medical centers in handling COVID-19 much more favorably compared to elected and public health officials, and they attribute the continued outbreak largely to insufficient public adherence to safety guidelines and the premature lifting of restrictions.

Political affiliations significantly impact perceptions of government responsibility during the COVID-19 pandemic.  There is a divide among the public regarding whether the federal government or state and local governments should be primarily responsible for managing policies to limit the spread of COVID-19 [2, 6].  While the public is almost evenly split on this issue [9], partisan views differ sharply. A majority of Republicans (68%) believe that state and local governments should bear the primary responsibility, whereas a majority of Democrats (64%) think the federal government should be primarily responsible [9]. ![Republicans favor state and local governments for COVID-19 policy responsibility, while Democrats prefer federal government responsibility.](image4)

Moreover, the perceived reasons for the continued COVID-19 outbreak are also influenced by political affiliation.  Insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing is widely recognized as a major contributing factor by most Americans [1].  This view is shared across party lines, with a large majority of Democrats (around nine-in-ten) and a narrower majority of Republicans (57%) citing insufficient adherence to social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines as a major reason for the continued outbreak [3]. ![A significant majority of Americans consider insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing a major reason for the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak.](image1) However, partisan divides emerge when considering other factors. Democrats are considerably more likely than Republicans to attribute the continued outbreak to an inadequate federal government response and the premature lifting of COVID-19 restrictions [5].  Notably, 82% of Democrats view the inadequate federal government response as a major reason, compared to only 21% of Republicans, and 82% of Democrats consider lifting restrictions too quickly a major reason, while only 31% of Republicans agree [5]. ![Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to consider inadequate federal response and premature lifting of restrictions as major reasons for the continued COVID-19 outbreak.](image5)

In conclusion, political affiliation strongly shapes perceptions of government responsibility and the reasons cited for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak, with notable differences between Democrats and Republicans on both aspects.

Based on political affiliations, there are significant differences in opinions on the primary reasons for the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak, especially concerning government response and social distancing.  Democrats are much more critical of the federal government's response, while both Democrats and Republicans acknowledge insufficient social distancing as a major factor.

Democrats overwhelmingly believe that an inadequate federal response is a major reason for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak in the U.S., with  $82\%$ holding this view [5]. In stark contrast, only $21\%$ of Republicans agree with this assessment, with nearly half ($45\%$) stating it is not a reason at all [9].  This partisan divide is further emphasized when considering whether lifting restrictions too quickly is a major reason. A large majority of Democrats ($82\%$) see this as a major factor, compared to only $31\%$ of Republicans [10].

![Democrats are far more likely than Republicans to view the federal government's response as inadequate and restrictions lifted too quickly as major reasons for the continued COVID-19 outbreak.](image5)

Furthermore, while a majority across both parties agree that insufficient social distancing is a major reason for the continued outbreak [2, 3, 6, 7, 8], the level of concern differs.  A large majority of Democrats (around 90%) view insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing as a major reason, while a narrower majority of Republicans (around 57%) share this view [7].  This suggests that while both groups recognize the importance of social distancing, Democrats perceive it as a more critical factor in the outbreak's continuation.

![A bar chart shows that 75% of total respondents believe that not enough people social distancing and mask-wearing is a major reason for the continued COVID-19 outbreak.](image4)

In conclusion, political affiliation significantly shapes perceptions of the reasons for the continued COVID-19 outbreak, with Democrats being more critical of the federal government's response and more concerned about insufficient social distancing than Republicans.

Democrats and Republicans diverge significantly in their assessment of the federal government's handling of the COVID-19 outbreak.  A large majority of Democrats, 82%, consider the federal response to be inadequate, a view held by only 21% of Republicans [3].  This partisan gap is particularly pronounced when evaluating the federal government's response as a major reason for the continuation of the outbreak [4].  Just 21% of Republicans agree that an inadequate federal response is a major factor, compared to the overwhelming majority of Democrats [1].

![Democrats are far more likely than Republicans to view the federal government's response as inadequate.](image1)

Overall, about half of Americans (53%) believe that an inadequate federal response is a major reason for the outbreak's persistence [5].  However, a consensus emerges across party lines regarding insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing.  Majorities in both Democratic and Republican coalitions agree that a lack of social distancing is a significant factor contributing to the ongoing outbreak [8].  Indeed, most Americans cite insufficient social distancing as a primary reason for the continued COVID-19 outbreak [10].

![Insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing is considered the top major reason for the continuation of the outbreak by Americans.](image5)

In summary, Democrats are far more critical of the federal government's COVID-19 response than Republicans, while insufficient social distancing is widely recognized as a major reason for the continued outbreak across the general public.

Partisan beliefs significantly diverge on the reasons for the COVID-19 outbreak's continuation. Republicans are more inclined to attribute blame to the Chinese government's initial response [1].  In contrast, Democrats are more likely to point towards domestic factors, particularly concerning the federal response and easing of restrictions.

Democrats overwhelmingly view the federal government's response as inadequate, with 82% citing it as a major reason for the continued outbreak [7].  This contrasts sharply with Republicans, where only 21% share this view, and nearly half (45%) believe it is not a reason at all [10].  ![Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to consider the federal government's COVID-19 response as a major reason for the outbreak to continue.](image3)

A substantial partisan gap exists regarding the easing of COVID-19 restrictions.  A large majority of Democrats (82%) believe that some places were too quick to ease restrictions, contributing significantly to the outbreak's continuation [5, 7].  Conversely, only 31% of Republicans agree with this, with a similar percentage stating it's not a reason at all [5]. ![Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to say that lifting restrictions too quickly in some places is a major reason for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak.](image2)

Regarding testing, Democrats are also significantly more likely than Republicans to consider "not enough timely testing" as a major factor in the outbreak's persistence in the U.S. [9].  Furthermore, when considering the increase in confirmed cases, Republicans are more inclined to believe it's primarily due to increased testing rather than new infections [6].  A majority of Republicans (62%) attribute the rise in cases to increased testing, while only 36% believe it's due to more new infections [6].  In contrast, most Americans (60%) overall attribute the rise to rising infections rather than increased testing [8]. ![Republicans are more likely than Democrats to believe increased testing is the primary reason for increased confirmed COVID-19 cases.](image4)

While a larger percentage of Republicans than Democrats think that controlling the spread is inherently difficult [3], majorities across both parties recognize insufficient social distancing as a significant factor in the outbreak's continuation [4].  ![Most people consider 'not enough people social distancing and mask-wearing' as a major reason for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak in the U.S.](image1)

In conclusion, partisan beliefs strongly influence perceptions of the reasons for the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak, with Democrats emphasizing federal response inadequacies and premature easing of restrictions, while Republicans are more likely to blame external factors and increased testing rates.

There is a notable partisan divide in perspectives on the reasons behind increasing coronavirus cases.  A majority of Republicans (62%) believe that the rise in confirmed cases is mainly due to increased testing, while only 36% think it's primarily due to new infections [6].  This view is particularly strong among conservative Republicans, with about two-thirds attributing the increase to more testing [6].  In contrast, Democrats overwhelmingly believe that the increase in cases is due to more infections rather than just increased testing [7].  Liberal Democrats especially hold this view more strongly than conservative and moderate Democrats [5].

![Republicans are more likely to attribute rising coronavirus cases to increased testing, while Democrats believe it is due to more infections.](image1)

Similarly, opinions on the pace of lifting state restrictions differ along party lines.  A significant majority of Democrats, both liberal (93%) and conservative/moderate (88%), are more concerned that state restrictions have been lifted too quickly [1].  Conversely, Republicans are more divided, with slightly more concerned that restrictions haven't been lifted quickly enough (53%) than those worried about them being lifted too quickly (45%) [8].  Conservative Republicans are particularly inclined to believe restrictions are not being lifted fast enough, while moderate and liberal Republicans are more concerned about the pace being too rapid [8].

![Democrats are overwhelmingly concerned that state restrictions have been lifted too quickly, while Republicans are more divided on this issue.](image2)

This partisan divergence extends to the perceived reasons for the continuation of the coronavirus outbreak.  A large majority of Democrats (82%) consider some places being too quick to ease restrictions as a major reason for the ongoing outbreak, whereas only 31% of Republicans share this view [9].

![Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to view the quick lifting of restrictions as a major reason for the continuation of the outbreak.](image5)

In conclusion, political affiliation strongly influences perspectives on both the causes of rising COVID-19 cases and the appropriateness of the pace at which state restrictions are being lifted.

Democrats and Republicans hold contrasting views on the reasons behind the increase in coronavirus cases, and these views are linked to their opinions on lifting COVID-19 restrictions. Republicans are more inclined to attribute the rise in cases to increased testing, while Democrats are more likely to believe it's due to new infections.

![Republicans are more likely to attribute increased cases to more testing, while Democrats believe it's due to more infections.](image5)

A majority of Republicans (62%) believe that the increase in confirmed coronavirus cases is mainly because of increased testing [5]. This perspective contrasts sharply with Democrats, a large majority of whom (around 80%) attribute the rise in cases to more new infections rather than just increased testing [9].

![Democrats are much more concerned that restrictions have been lifted too quickly.](image4)

Correspondingly, Democrats are overwhelmingly more concerned that state restrictions have been lifted too quickly [2].  Overwhelming shares of Democrats, both liberal (93%) and conservative/moderate (88%), express greater concern about restrictions being lifted too quickly [2].  In contrast, Republicans are more divided, with slightly more concerned that restrictions haven't been lifted quickly enough (53%) than that they have been lifted too quickly (45%) [1].

![There is a significant partisan gap on whether lifting restrictions too quickly is a major reason for the continued outbreak.](image3)

This partisan divide extends to the perception of whether easing restrictions too quickly is a major factor in the continued outbreak, with 82% of Democrats considering it a major reason, compared to only 31% of Republicans [3, 6].

In conclusion, Democrats are more likely to believe rising COVID-19 cases are due to increased infections and are concerned about restrictions being lifted too quickly, whereas Republicans are more inclined to attribute rising cases to increased testing and are less concerned about restrictions being lifted too quickly.

Differences in voting policy preferences are evident across racial and ethnic groups, particularly regarding the requirement of government-issued photo identification for voting [1]. While a narrow majority of White Democrats support this requirement, larger proportions of Black, Hispanic, and Asian Democrats favor it [2].

![Larger shares of Black, Hispanic and Asian Democrats favor requiring government-issued photo identification to vote.](image2)

However, Black adults generally exhibit lower support for restrictive voting policies like photo ID requirements compared to other groups [8].  In contrast, Republicans overwhelmingly support the policy of requiring government-issued photo ID to vote [3].

![Republicans continue to overwhelmingly support requiring government-issued photo ID to vote.](image2)

In conclusion, racial and political affiliations significantly influence preferences on voter ID laws, with minority Democrats showing higher support than White Democrats, and Republicans showing overwhelming support overall.

Racial and ethnic differences significantly shape opinions on voting policies. For instance, Black adults show a stronger preference for ‘no excuse’ early voting compared to White, Hispanic, and Asian adults [1]. This aligns with broader trends where Black Americans often favor more expansive voting policies [6].  ![Black adults are more in favor of no excuse early voting compared to other races.](image3)

Interestingly, while some might expect minority groups to oppose stricter voting laws, data reveals a nuanced picture regarding voter identification.  Although a narrow majority of White Democrats favor requiring government-issued photo ID, larger proportions of Black, Hispanic, and Asian Democrats support this requirement [2].  This is visually represented in the data showing that 65% of Black Democrats, 72% of Hispanic Democrats, and 71% of Asian Democrats favor photo ID, compared to 54% of White Democrats. ![Hispanic Democrats are more in favor of requiring photo ID to vote compared to White Democrats.](image5)

However, it's crucial to note that Black adults also exhibit among the lowest support for some restrictive voting policies overall [4]. This might seem contradictory, but it highlights the complexity of opinions within racial groups and the specific policies being considered.  The differences in views on voting policies are present across both political parties, indicating that race and ethnicity are important factors in shaping these opinions beyond just party affiliation [3].

In conclusion, racial and ethnic backgrounds are significant factors influencing support for voting policies, with Black adults notably favoring more expansive options like early voting, and minority Democrats surprisingly showing stronger support for voter ID requirements compared to White Democrats.

Racial and political affiliations play a significant role in shaping opinions on voter ID requirements and voting accessibility policies. While voter identification is broadly favored, strong partisan divides exist, with Republicans showing much stronger support than Democrats [9].  Republicans are considerably more likely to *strongly* favor photo ID requirements for voting, with 81% in strong favor compared to only 30% of Democrats [9].

![Democrats of color are more likely to favor voter ID than White Democrats.](image1)

Interestingly, racial differences emerge even within the Democratic party on the issue of voter ID.  Although a narrow majority of White Democrats favor voter photo ID requirements, larger proportions of Black, Hispanic, and Asian Democrats support this policy [6]. For instance, 72% of Hispanic Democrats and 71% of Asian Democrats favor voter ID, contrasting with 54% of White Democrats [6].

When considering voting accessibility policies, such as early voting or absentee voting, viewpoints also diverge along racial and political lines.  White Democrats are notably supportive of policies that make voting easier, sometimes even more so than Democrats of other racial and ethnic backgrounds [1].  For example, White Democrats are more supportive of allowing all voters to vote early or absentee compared to Democrats of other races [2].

![Democrats are more likely to support no-excuse absentee voting, with strong racial differences within the party.](image5)

However, among Republicans, White adults are less supportive of easing voting compared to Hispanic adults [3].  Overall, White adults tend to be less in favor of measures that enhance voting access, like making Election Day a national holiday or automatically registering eligible citizens, than are Black, Hispanic, and Asian adults [4].  Black adults, in particular, often express a preference for more expansive voting policies [7].

In conclusion, perspectives on voter ID and voting accessibility are significantly shaped by both racial and political affiliations, revealing nuanced differences within and between parties, especially regarding the balance between voter security measures like photo ID and broader voting access policies.

The public shows general support for the proposal by House Democrats to establish independent redistricting commissions, with nearly half of U.S. adults approving it [8]. However, partisan divisions exist, with Democrats being more in favor than Republicans.  ![About half of all US adults approve the proposal for independent redistricting commission, while only about 38% of Republican/lean Republican approve this proposal.](image2).  Regarding early or absentee voting, there is general support among Americans for allowing any voter to vote early or absentee [6].  ![63% of total voters agree that any voter should have the option to vote early or absentee.](image1).  However, partisan divides are significant here as well.  Only 38% of Republicans favor allowing all voters to vote early or absentee, a view that has decreased by 19 percentage points recently [3, 7].  In contrast, Democrats overwhelmingly support no-excuse early voting [7].  ![84% of Democrat/lean Democrat agree that any voter should have the option to vote early or absentee.](image1).  Within the Republican party, ideology plays a role, with conservative Republicans being more likely to prefer documented reasons for absentee or early voting compared to moderate and liberal Republicans [9].  Furthermore, Republicans who voted absentee in 2020 are more supportive of no-excuse absentee voting than those who voted in person [1, 4, 5].  ![About half of Republicans who voted absentee or by mail in 2020 favor no-excuse absentee or early voting, while only about 22% of those who voted in person on election day say the same.](image4).  Racial differences also emerge, with White Democrats being less supportive of early or absentee voting compared to Democrats of other races and ethnicities; the opposite is true for White Republicans compared to Hispanic Republicans [2].

In summary, while there is broad support for both independent redistricting commissions and no-excuse early/absentee voting, significant partisan divisions exist, with Democrats being more supportive than Republicans, and demographic factors like ideology and voting history further shaping these views, particularly within the Republican party.

Based on the provided data, political affiliations significantly shape views on both voting methods and redistricting proposals.  Regarding redistricting, a proposal to shift control from state legislatures to independent commissions composed of equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans garners approximately half of adult approval [1, 3]. However, partisan lines are evident, as Republicans are more inclined to either disapprove or express uncertainty towards these non-legislative commissions compared to Democrats [8].

![Democrats are more likely to approve of redistricting commissions than Republicans, while Republicans are more likely to be unsure](image5)

In terms of voting methods, particularly early or absentee voting, partisan affiliation also plays a role.  Individuals with recent experience in early or absentee voting are more likely to support no-excuse early and absentee voting options, a trend especially pronounced among Republicans [6].  Notably, Republicans who utilized absentee or mail-in voting in the 2020 election demonstrate greater support for no-excuse absentee or early voting compared to their counterparts who voted in person [7, 10]. This difference in opinion within the Republican party based on their past voting method is illustrated in the data.

![Republicans who voted absentee are more likely to favor no-excuse absentee or early voting compared to those who voted in person](image3)

Despite this internal variation within the Republican party, when considering the broader question of whether any voter should have the option to vote early or absentee, Democrats show considerably higher levels of support than Republicans.

![Democrats are more likely to believe any voter should have the option to vote early or absentee compared to Republicans](image4)

In summary, the data indicates that political affiliation is a key determinant in opinions on voting methods and redistricting, with Democrats generally favoring more accessible voting options and independent redistricting commissions, while Republican views are more nuanced and internally divided based on factors like past voting behavior.

The views of Republicans and Democrats have diverged notably between 2018 and 2021 regarding 'no excuse' early or absentee voting and automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote. For 'no excuse' early or absentee voting, Republicans have shown a significant decrease in support since 2018 [3]. In April 2021, only $38\%$ of Republicans favored allowing any voter to vote early or absentee without a documented reason, a sharp decline from $57\%$ in 2018 [5]. This contrasts sharply with Democrats, whose support for no-excuse early voting has remained consistently high at $84\%$ and virtually unchanged since 2018 [5].

![Republicans' support for no-excuse early or absentee voting has declined from 57% in October 2018 to 38% in April 2021, while Democrats' support has remained stable at around 83%.](image2)

Regarding automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote, a similar trend is observed.  Republican support for this policy has decreased from $49\%$ in 2018 to $38\%$ in 2021 [7].  Conversely, Democrats have consistently shown strong support for automatic voter registration, with $82\%$ favoring it, and their views have remained stable over the years [1, 5].

![Republican support for automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote has decreased from 49% in October 2018 to 38% in April 2021, while Democrats' support has remained stable at around 82%.](image3)

In summary, Republican support for both 'no excuse' early or absentee voting and automatically registering citizens has decreased from 2018 to 2021, while Democrats' views on both issues have remained stable and strongly in favor.

The survey data indicates diverging trends in partisan opinions regarding making Election Day a national holiday and requiring photo ID for voting.  While Democrats have become more inclined to support making Election Day a national holiday, Republicans' views on this matter have remained stable since 2018 [1].

![Democrats support for making Election Day a national holiday increased from Oct '18 to Apr '21 while Republican support remained relatively stable.](image2)

Conversely, there has been little shift in views on requiring photo ID to vote since 2018, with Republicans maintaining overwhelming support for this policy [6].  Republicans are considerably more likely than Democrats to strongly favor photo identification requirements, even though majorities in both groups favor it [4].  In fact, Republicans are much less likely to strongly support making Election Day a national holiday compared to Democrats [5].

![Republican support for requiring photo ID to vote remained high from Oct '18 to Apr '21 while Democratic support remained lower.](image2)

In conclusion, partisan views have diverged on making Election Day a national holiday with Democrats becoming more supportive, while views on photo ID requirements have remained stable with persistent partisan division.
